description:
s p i c y f i s h
is what I came for. and is indeed what I received.

In the quest for the best spicy fish, this restaurant has ranked #1 so far in delivery. Szechuan food is delicious when properly executed and Sichuan Home is as good as it gets in SF. 

We opted for the spicy fish, cucumber salad, duck, walnut shrimp, and two more dishes I am forgetting (and sadly did not take any photos of). My brother wholeheartedly appreciated the duck while I was a huge fan of spicy fish. The walnut shrimp was also very tasty, better than the ones I've had in the Sunset.

Remember they really pack on the spice here so if you've got a weak spice tolerance, let them know! 

Waitress was super sweet and gave recommendations on each page, depending on our tastes. Would recommend if you want a homey Szechuan meal
author: Arezou A.

description:
Dan Dan noodle was a big disappointment and they still
Charged me even tho I didn't eat it. Only had one bite. 
The fish soup was good. The tofu with duck egg and the spicy beef were good. My sister liked the pumpkin rice cake I thought It was to oily and blah.
I prob will never return here bcuz it's out of the way and way better places to get dandan noodles and similar food
author: Lika G.

description:
I came here for dinner on a Monday night with my girlfriend and we were seated immediately. Starving, we ordered 4 different things: (Not spicy) Fish stew, pea sprouts, dan dan noodles, and spicy wontons.

The fish stew was significantly bigger than I thought it would be and it was pretty good with nice flavor and delicious flakey fish. Not spicy at all. Was perfect for the cold weather outside. The pea sprouts were phenomenal and that garlic they cook it in was the star of the dish. Nice to see this restaurant offering pea sprouts at a reasonable price. Dan dan noodles were tasty and had that signature szechuan spice, where it's clear and tingly, but doesn't hurt. It just kind of is there to brighten up the flavor. The spicy wontons were average. Always a good choice, but didn't blow me away.

Overall, a very good spot for Szechuan food in the Richmond district, especially if you're in the area and not trying to wait a long time for a table.
author: Phillip V.

description:
This place has been a consistently good Sichuan restaurant in San Francisco. There aren't too many spicy Chinese restaurants in the city overall, so we're glad to have a delicious option when we're craving spicy Chinese food. 

Their boiling fish hot pot is really popular, and for good reason. For people who aren't familiar with Chinese food, they bring it out on a small, personalized burner that keeps the dish hot while you're eating it. This makes the dish more interesting and delicious because the longer the broth is simmering, the more flavorful the dish becomes. Note: they are not joking around with the peppers. It's going to burn going in and coming out. Highly recommend. 

We've also tried the following: 
- hot wonton spicy soup: pretty good, but we've had better (pretty average, wouldn't get it again)
- pan fried lotus: they slice the lotus very thin and after it's fried, it almost taste like a lotus chip; would get this again
- chef's special fried chicken: it's good but has a lot of bones and skin
- pan fried frog & vegetable combo: pretty good, but we've had better

Overall, we're happy to have this restaurant close by! However, it's not quite a five because there hasn't been any outstanding dishes. 

Lastly, the service has been really great every time we go. They even gave us free pumpkin sesame rice cakes the last time we visited! This dish is delicious but very calorically dense...probably not worth ordering because there's better items to spend your calories on :)
author: Yuchen L.

description: Dan San Noooodles!!!!!!  Szechuan restaurants in San Francisco are limited,  honestly I've not been impressed with SF for hot spicy food. Sure, there's tons of tasty food, and some with spices. None with real heat. Sichuan home a least offers one outlet. I wouldn't say crazy heat and you have to ask for it. The food is delicious rather you like heat or not through. The base menu item is not spicy so feel safe to enjoy.
author: L J.

description:
Pretty decent food and superb hospitality. The staff were all so kind and attentive which is a rare find in Chinese joints in general.

We had the spicy fish, egg tofu, and spicy wontons. Nothing really outside the box or special but it's a real, feel-good meal. They had the mala factor down for the fish and it was pretty amazing.
author: Joyce Z.

description:
Sichuan home was a fun experience with the fam! It was a little warm in the restaurant, but not enough to not enjoy being there. I appreciate that Sichuan Home knew what their best dishes were and really advertised those! We ordered some of my personal favorites and I did not love the way they were cooked here. The Chongqing Chicken was mostly breading. I'm used to having a good amount of meat, but this didn't have much meat to it. A lot of the pieces were just gristle or fat deep fried in batter. It was pretty heavily salty too. The beef stew we ordered was good, but I felt like it wasn't as flavorful as it should have been- especially the beef. If I took a piece of beef out and bit into it without a lot of the other stuff, it just tasted like roast beef. It's almost like it hadn't simmered for a long time for all of the flavors to really seep in? I'm not completely sure. 

Overall it was a great experience, it just wasn't the best Sichuan food I have personally had. However, I would recommend for anyone to give them a try! I love new experiences and appreciated this place!
author: Hillary S.

description:
There's a special place in my heart for deep fried Tilapia (it reminds me of a time when my granny, my aunt and I would go to the local Ranch 99 and pick out live Tilapia that was then prepared and deep fried on the spot).

I sometimes get the urge to get it and this time, I took the 38 bus to the Richmond and went to Sichuan Home.  I ordered the whole fish with sweet and sour sauce and it was fabulous - amazingly, the fish wasn't too greasy and wasn't too fishy either (Tilapia can get really fishy).  

They gave me some pickled seaweed/veggies as amuse and a hot red bean dessert together with the meal. Hot tea was also complementary. Service was good and the restaurant is what you'd expect from a neighborhood Chinese place that's been around for a while.  With tax and tip, this meal was $24.  Highly recommended!!!  I can definitely see why this place landed on the Michelin Bib Gourmand list.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Craving Chinese, my friend and I chose this place seeing the good reviews and wanting something in the Richmond neighborhood. Needless to say, it was a great choice! Though I have not been to the Sichuan Province of China, it felt like I was back in the country.

The food is affordable and great for family style. We shared a fish and eggplant dish and had leftovers to spare. Be prepared for spice but the taste is worth the extra glass of water. Meals come with tea and we were given a dessert at the end free of charge. 

I was pleasantly surprised by the service as well. I don't expect service to be the best in Asian restaurants due to differences in culture and service, but the staff was on top of everything from filling waters to putting our food in to go containers. While the restaurant is farther out from where I live, I hope to make a return!
author: Brandon S.

description:
I've been on a Sichuan binge since the weather has cooled down. We came here for dinner after climbing, parking was a biotch, I parked on 20th and walked 5 blocks. 

We had to wait about 20 min on a Sunday night,  not bad.  The waitresses here are super super friendly!!!! All smiles and everything, which I usually don't get at a Chinese restaurant. 

We ordered the chong qing spicy deep fried chicken, and the boiled steam fish in a hot pot. 

The steam fish hot pot is worth the extra  $10, it's super hot and fresh. The soup is sooo tasty with rice, and you'll have leftovers for days.  The chong qing fried chicken was too salty for me.  

Great little place to order food to go as well, or even dine by oneself. Food portions are large so you willl have plenty to go.
author: Tiffany Y.

description: Delicious food, good service especially for a Thursday evening, reasonable prices and a CLEAN bathroom! Just what I need to be a repeat customer :) I'll be back!!
author: Sen S.

description:
We ordered from here last night for the first time and I definitely think we will be back soon! 

The Food:
We ordered 4 dishes:
1. Chongqing Style Spicy Chicken (Medium)
2. Beef Chow Fun
3. Black Mushroom and Tender Green
4. Lamb in Cumin Sauce (Mild)

The spicy chicken was very tasty although there were a lot of bones, so probably not suitable for young children.  The beef chow fun was pretty tasty--not the best flavor I've ever had, but was decent.  I really enjoyed both the black mushroom and tender greens and the lamb in cumin sauce.  Both had very good flavors! 
 
We ordered through the Yelp website and the food took about 25 min.  Upon arrival, the staff was very helpful and friendly!
author: Lynne T.

description:
We recently tried Sichuan Home because we got our hearts set on sichuan cuisine only to discover that Chili Hose is closed on Tuesdays. Not sure how we never noticed before.

I'm sure that Sichuan Home has some dishes they do very well. The servers were very nice, the restaurant was clean and smelled good, and most of the stuff coming out on plates looked good. But, unfortunately, I can only review what I tried. What I ordered was basically just our sichuan go-tos, and I'll address them individually.


Chongqing Style Chicken (explosive chili chicken, la zi ji) - Texture was unusual. Most places don't use this kind of breading, and I think it's better without. These were kind of halfway between the usual texture and a western-style chicken strip. The flavor was fine, and they give a lot of chicken. 3.5/5

Dan Dan Noodles (tan tan) - The dan dan at Sichuan Home were definitely the weakest link for me. There was a lot of ma and not a lot of la going on. In other words, very numbing/tingly but not much else going on. Also, the ultimate noodle sin - mushy noodles. 2/5

Pea Sprout in Garlic Sauce (dau miu w/ garlic) - This was exactly as expected. Hard to mess up too bad, but hey, credit where credit is due. 5/5


All in all, I want to try some different dishes. I think that my standard order is not their strength. That place smells sooo good.
author: Austin M.

description: YESSS THIS PLACE IS AMAZING (minus some shady stuff). I still drool and dream about their spicy fish in hot oil soup dish (not sure what it's called exactly but it's one of their highlighted specialities). Don't get pressured by the pushy waitress lady to add additional things like veggies or fish cake or fish balls or whatever she's tryna sell because you will be hit by huge add on fees on your bill (I was a victim of this sadly. I cave under pressure from salespeople). It was something ridiculous liken $3 for tofu, $3 for some bok choi, $3 for mushrooms etc. Rice is also sold separately. Their dan dan noodles are pretty decent as well.
author: Iris W.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend around 6 p.m. on a Thursday night, and it was pretty empty for the two hours or so we were eating here. I don't do well with spicy food but came anyways since my friend was craving their fish stew.

To be honest, most of the menu was full of spicy dishes, so I didn't have a huge selection to choose from. I ended up going with an order of chicken wings ($10.95) as well as a bowl of their chicken and corn soup ($7.95).

The chicken wings are dipped in batter, fried, and served in a wooden tray with nice presentation. Sprinkled on top are a lot of what tasted like garlic bread crumbs, which added an extra crunch and some garlicky flavor to the chicken wings. The chicken and corn soup was sweet rather than savory, which threw me off a little bit as I was expecting something savory, but it was still good.

My friend ordered the fish stew from the chef's specials page of the menu. It was extremely spicy, and she had to stop maybe 1/3 of the way through. She seemed to really enjoy it, so I would recommend this dish for the spicy food lovers out there.

Maybe it was because the restaurant was pretty empty, but our server was very attentive and checked in on us multiple times throughout the evening.
author: Dianna H.

description: Can't believe my last review is so old.  This is a great restaurant if you like Szechuan food.  Every dish is done well.  Last night we had our favorite, Chef Special Vegetables, boneless pan fried chicken, pea sprouts and garlic.  That combination is awesome.  We have tried many other dishes over the years, still our favorite Szechuan restaurant.  Service is always good, portions are large, food is always super fresh, the woks are always going.  Fun spot in the hood.   Perfect spicy, creative dishes.
author: Carole W.

description:
I love Sichuan food, I usually have dinner here with my family at least twice a month. After I tried lots of Sichuan restaurants in Bay Area, I found out that Sichuan home is the best! I learned from the waitress, their chef is from Sichuan. He has been cooking for more than 20 years. Their Sichuan food is authentic! I had dinner here last week with my family to try out their new dish, I decided to write a review about it to let more people know this great place. 
We ordered the spicy fish & chinese herb spice, chong qing style spicy chicken, sweet and sour fish with pinenuts, pork shoulder in black bean sauce, and beef in special chili sauce. 
The spicy fish and Chong Qing spicy chicken are my favorite dishes here. I must to have them every time I come here. 
They use fresh fish for the sweet and sour fish with pinenuts while most of the other Sichuan restaurants use frozen fishes. 
The beef in special chili sauce is their new item and it is my new favorite now ! The beef is so tasty, I was told that the process of cooking this dish is very complicate. 
Overall, I always have great experience at Sichuan Home with their authentic Sichuan food and great service! Servers are very friendly and offer the best services.
author: Fei F.

description: My favorite dish: sliced pork &garlic sauce !!!I have to say that's the best dish that I've ever had in town!!! Can't remember all the English names of each dish, but all taste really good. Will definitely visit again!
author: Rita H.

description: Come for new dishes, so yummy~ come here for lunch around 12 pm​, the fish stew is the best before, but after this time, I believe they will have more popular​ food on the list.
author: Faye L.

description:
Wow....very impressed with the authentic Chinese food.  Even though it is a Sichuan style, many of the dishes have flavors similar to the Yantai/Shandong and Heibei provinces.

I ordered the Chongching spicy chicken and it was spot on with the same dish from my visit to Chongching, China.  Dericious!  The portions are large enough for two, so family style sharing is ideal for trying lots of dishes.

The restaurant is clean and there is a bathroom for customers thru the kitchen.  There are two large tables of 8 for big groups.

5 stars from Phish!
author: Hot O.

description:
What a disappointing meal! 

Came here on a Saturday after visiting the de Young museum. Was craving authentic Chinese and decided to check out Sichuan Home in Inner Richmond because of good reviews. 

I scored a street parking directly in front of the restaurant and walked in. Wait staff spoke Chinese and most customers spoke Chinese so it looked very promising. 

I ordered the chef special fish stew recommended on Yelp, green beans, and pan fried baos. My meal also came with complimentary side seaweed and spicy cabbage (similar to kimchi). 

My waitress was very friendly and got my dishes quickly. I didn't quite get why ppl raved about that fish stew, It was average IMO. The green beans and the pan fried baos weren't too bad but they were nothing to write home about.

Towards the end of my meal, I discovered a string of hair in the complimentary side dish. I pointed it out the the wait staff. They just brushed it off and asked if I wanted a new one. I said no. Then they brought my bill, around $37 including tax. I asked if they could do anything about it b/c there was hair in my food. He said no because the hair was in the complimentary side dish. Interesting. If I find a hair in a side dish, then it is only logical to question the rest of the food they serve, no? 

I paid for my bill, left a small tip, and left. Coming from SoCal, I've had way better and cheaper Chinese in the 626 and Irvine for instance. The food here can't compare and is overpriced. The truth is I don't think this place is worth it and I don't have plans to ever return. My search for authentic Chinese continues.  

Finally, thanks for the complimentary hair I guess?
author: Angela F. W.

description:
Sichuan Home is my go-to spot for quality, authentic Chinese food. Every time I come here, I have an amazing meal. Some of my personal favorites off the top of my head - the chef's special fish stew, spicy eggplant, chongqing chicken, Hong Kong style dumplings, spicy tea duck, don don noodles, twice cooked pork, and the house special chicken. You honestly can't go wrong here. 

Your meal always starts with house made pickled seaweed and cabbage and ends with a delectable 5 conji soup (desert) to settle your stomach. Parking in this area sucks after around 630pm so be warned.
author: Chris O.

description: Their spicy fish  & Chinese herb spice and the vegetable combo are my favorite, must order whenever I came here. Sichuan Home definitely is one of the most authentic Sichuan cuisine you can find in SF.
author: Sunny M.

description: I ordered the Garlic Chicken Wings is so delicious, juicy inside with the crispy skin! We ate it all immediately then I realized I forgot to take photo! :p And the other dishes: Lamb in cumin sauce, House special chicken, sweet and sour pork ribs are so yummy with a reasonable price. You won't regret to be dining here!
author: W J.

description: Sooo good! Prob my new favorite place to eat! I'm definitely coming back for their spicy broccoli beef!! I can still taste it on my lips lol
author: Austin J.

description:
I used to dream of the days back in Philly where we had authentic sichuan style chinese food at our favorite restaurant. Since moving out to the bay area, we have been searching for a restaurant like the one we had in Philly and I can finally say we have found it. The spicy levels were perfect and off the charts here. Those dan dan noodles will really clear up your sinuses - it's massively packed with spice so don't order this if you are even the tiniest bit squemish.

Food:
Wontons in spicy sauce - yummy! I couldn't stop eating these. The pork filling was delicious. The sauce was medium-hot.
Honey walnut prawns - I didn't want to order this but my husband insisted because he loves the creamy mayo sauce. I ended up loving this dish too. It was a good balance to the other spicy dishes we ordered and gave us a little palate cleanser from the heat.
Dan Dan Noodles - WOW was this spicy. Way more spice than I expected and man it was soooo good. My mouth was on fire, I kept pounding the water, my body temperature felt like it rose a few degrees, and both my husband and I were sweating. And yet neither of us could stop eating this dish.
Cumin style beef - So flavorful; jam packed with cumin and pepper flakes. The beef was so tender. This dish wasn't super spicy even though it looked like it would be with all the red pepper flakes but it was so full of flavor.

Only downside was that it was just the two of us and we really wanted to order more food but was too stuffed to do so. I highly recommend coming with a few more people so that you can order more dishes and then share family style. 

The menu was huge and a little overwhelming. But it did have lots of pictures which helped with ordering. 

Service was really good too. It felt homey and the ladies were so nice to us. They even gave us a little dessert and extra rice with our to-go boxes, all on the house.

It's a really small restaurant so I could see this place having a long wait on the weekends. The biggest round tables looked like it could fix max 8 people.

Price was good. The fish dishes are a premium but everything else was reasonable and didn't feel overpriced.
author: Lisa D.

description: Very good authentic Chinese restaurant, the prices are reasonable, the staff is fast and friendly. The food tastes like in China, I can highly recommend this place
author: Moritz S.

description: Favorite Chinese food! Yummy dim sum, yummy vegetable, me a happy girl. Shengjianbao on point! Would eat here on the weekly if I lived closer.
author: Mackenzie W.

description:
Found this place through Yelp and decided to check it out because of their good reviews but was sadly disappointed by my visit.

Their food was very tasty, but the service was irritating. Once we were seated and handed menus, we had to fetch for someone to take our order because no one cared to help us out. The restaurant is not very big. The workers came by our table multiple times, but no one came to check on our table. Then we were handed our hot, sour soup. The soup was delicious, but water was much needed with the meal. And again, after having to fetch for a waiter multiple times, we didn't receive water until we were half way through our meal. 
The waiters never voluntarily came by to help us the entire time. I spent more time trying to get someone's attention than eating my food.

The reason I gave them a one star is because of our check. We noticed the check was higher than expected, so we looked over the receipt. There was a $15 dollar charge that we could not decipher. After a good 10 minutes of reviewing the receipt, we were told the charge was the tip... that they gave themselves, without giving us prior knowledge.
If we did not thoroughly review our receipt, we would have tipped them twice without knowing it.
Lesson learned y'all, review your receipts!!!
author: Alexis B.

description: This used to be one of my favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco. Alas the cook has changed and unfortunately cannot match the quality and flavors that used to bless this place. This was my last visit and despite the great friendly service, I will not come back.
author: Cedrick C.

description:
Awesome Sichuan that doesnt burn going in, but it sure does burn coming out!

I've had my fair share of spicy food. From the kinda where you get the immediate hit and youre drenched in your own sweat to the kind where your face goes numb.  However, at Sichuan Home, the at burn is a sloooooooow burn.  It didnt feel very spicy while eating, so you could enjoy the other qualities of the food. The cumin lamb was well seasoned. The dry mushroom was crisp. If you're going to get the chongqing chicken, get it with bones. The without bones are just tiny bits of dice chicken.

Staff was helpful even though they spoke limited english. They were never pushy. Oh yea, if youre fatty like me and always welcome big portions, then come here.
author: Jason C.

description: Wonderful hospitality, genuinely friendly staff, very tasty, high quality food in a lively setting. Conscious about vegan preferences. Definitely my favorite Sichuan Chinese restaurant in San Francisco. Will be back for sure.
author: Sudhamsu J.

description: Everything we ordered was super tasty. It definitely satisfied our spicy craving. Will be back!
author: Ji Young J.

description:
Every time my parents would come visit me, I would bring them here!  WElove Sichuan food and this place really hits the spot! 

I love that they give you complimentary pickled vegetables at the beginning

I definitely recommend the Chef's special fish stew! It's so good, and the portion is massive, so you'll probably have some leftover! 5/5

I also usually order this chicken dish that comes in a bamboo steamer pot (can't remember what it's called exactly) ! It's so good (and not spicy) but I love the sauce it comes with it. 5/5

Spicy Beef Short Ribs are good too! They give you alot of peppers, but don't worry the spice is pretty manageable. 

The only thing I don't recommend is the Lobster Lo Mein... my dad fell once for the waitress pitching it to us as a special. It was a rip off, there was not a lot of lobster and the noodles weren't very flavorful or memorable. 

Stick with classic Sichuan dishes (dan dan noodles are also solid here!) and you'll be good to go! Also, most dishes are usually a little on the oily-er side!
author: Kristie M.

description:
I was in the mood to have a szechuan style whole fish. I was in that neighborhood and saw that Sichuan House had "29 Whole Fish and Spicy Bean Sauce" on their menu. The picture looked good and they have a lot of good reviews. That was enough research for me and it was 5 minutes away. We were going to get the fish and some chow mein. When I ordered I asked what type of fish they used. I just wanted to know for reference what I was eating. She immediately said that it's frozen and that some people like frozen and some prefer fresh, but if we wanted fresh fish, the price went to $38 from about $17. She said it's "just a little bit more", but that it cost them more for fresh fish. 

$38 might be the going rate for that dish in SF. That's ok if it is. But, I chose Sichuan House because they had the dish that I was looking for at a decent price and their reputation. If the menu listed frozen @ $17 and fresh @ $38, that would have been fine, but I didn't appreciate the up-charge.

I didn't want to spend that much and was annoyed about the situation. We got two other dishes that I would describe as mediocre. I'm guessing that maybe when people don't ask any questions about the fish, that they don't offer the "advice" that we got. The up-side is that she gave us honest advice.

If it wasn't for the up-charge, it would have been a 3-star for me.
author: Leo S.

description: Fantastic flavor and service! If you're seeking a "Panda Express" experience, this isn't the place for you! The food was extremely flavorful and abundant. We had: wontons in chili sauce (8 out of 10); Mongolian beef (8); hot and sour soup (8); and the fish stew (9). Oh, and a few beers. Way, way too much food for 2, but the left overs were fantastic. Total bill was around $70+ tip. Seems reasonable (?). Try it if you're seeking good food!
author: J J.

description: Large menu. Quick friendly service. Yum flavors. We ordered whole fish with black bean sauce, onion pancake, dry fried green beans, and sesame pumpkin rice cakes. The fish sauce was great, rich and full ginger. The fish was huge, we didn't even eat half of it. It didn't taste the freshest, prolly was frozen, but with the tasty sauce and all the leftovers who can complain. Green beans were perfectly cooked and loaded with crispy and soft bits of garlic. Nom. Surprise mung bean dessert, leave room!
author: Audrey S.

description: My favorite Sichuan restaurant in Bay Area. Excellent food with friendly services. Pan fried chicken with potato and lotus is my all time favorite. Their spicy fish &chinese herb spice tastes authentic and yum. Last but not least, you need to try the pork shoulder with black bean sauce, pork shoulder is tendon and juicy, match with black bean sauce perfectly, highly recommended!!
author: L T.

description: This restaurant does not deliver. GRUBhub says it does, but it in fact does not.  So I instead had to go pick it up. Food is fantastic and when I spoke to the manager he mentioned it was a common mistake. Threw in a side dish on the house, which was unnecessary but made the trip to go across town to pick it up more bearable. Staff is great. Ask for May - she's fun and will help you navigate he menu.
author: Joshua K.

description:
This place has one of the best food in town.
Get the dish soup- the pork eggplant and the Sichuan dry chicken!!
The service is great and they are all very friendly.
author: Imelda G.

description:
I like this place. It was quiet on a Sunday lunch time.
Service was attentive and the restaurant was pretty empty.
I was also hung over so this all suit me really well.
Boyfriend and I ordered one hot and sour soup, one the hot beef soup and one pan fried dumplings.

The hot and sour soup was on point. It wasn't as sour as I hoped it would be but it was delicious. The pan fried dumplings were alright. I was kinda hoping there would be soup in them but they were still pretty delicious, the bread wasn't too thick and the filling was just the right amount of flavoring. The beef soup though was kinda weird. I wanted like the hot beef soup at Spices 3! (in Oakland) but their noodles are weirder so i'm not sure about that.
author: Mimi T.

description:
up there with the worst kung pao chicken i've ever ordered. to be fair, the people in the restaurant were really nice. but nice doesn't make chicken taste better (just not worse :) )

despite the high number of sliced red chilis (what a pain to eat around, keep them whole, man!) this dish was B to the LAND. BLAND BLAND BLAND (mind you, this is a spicy dish known for lots of flavor). i had to add my own flavor at home. 

it was cheap, so there's that. 

no, i won't go back (and i'm having a v. hard time understanding the four star average reviews). oh yelp....
author: Wendy X.

description:
Sauteed lettuce, cumin lamb and spicy fish are all tasty. 

You will need a glass of fresh banana milk to help with the Sichuan burn :D 

Or two glasses, because they are so delicious.
author: Angie C.

description: Chef's Special Fish & Picked Mustard-Green is not delicious.The fish is not fresh.Tasted terrible.A lot of people can cook better than this restaurant.In China,a lot of restaurants can cook delicious.In San Francisco less restaurants can cook good.Shrimp is just ok.Service attitude is ok,so gave 3 stars,if service also not ok,just worth 2 stars.
author: Stephanie M.

description: First time coming here for a quick lunch - the value alone (price vs portion) is excellent. We (2) ordered combo won ton soup, sauté garlic bok Choy, House fried rice and Hunan spicy pork - everything was fresh and tasty. We had enough leftover for another meal. The service is great - our hostess was energetic and enthusiastic.  We will definitely recommend and come back again.
author: Josie S.

description:
When I'm not eating at Sichuan Home, I'm dreaming of eating here. My partner and I came two weekends in a row. It was really that serious. 

First time was a Sunday afternoon around 3pm. Luckily there was a table ready though the place was packed with big groups enjoying their lunchtime as well. Super authentic! Chinese families were gettin' down with wine and beer and the beloved lazy Susan. 

I have not had dan dan noodles in ages. A bowl by itself is large enough to be a huge solo meal. We shared the dan dan and pan fried chicken -- you can choose between boneless and bone in. We also ordered a plate of the garlic cucumber and a plate of the pan fried pork buns. Everything was literally 5/5. The food comes out quickly and so hot.

Dan Dan - 5/5 lovely chewy loooong noodles in the chili oil. It was more soupy instead of oily and perfectly done. 

Pan Fried Pork Buns 5/5- the freshest and softest buns I've ever had. Meat is good, but the bun ins the star here. 

Pan Fried Chicken 5/5- Simply amazing. We made sure to order this again on our second trip one week later. The dish includes these little bites of fried tofu that has a sour flavor and it's SO GOOD.

Garlic cucumber 4/5- a little pricey for what it is, and I wish they'd add some spices but yummy nonetheless. 

Second time around we had to wait about an hour on a Friday night. The place was packed. Definitely make reservations! We tried a couple new dishes --

Beef Short Ribs - 5/5 similar to the pan fried chicken, but the tender beef pieces still makes it unique and not redundant in flavor. 

Wontons in chili oil - 5/5 Some of the best I've had. Chili oil flavor is to die for and much different than the dan dan. 

This is our new Chinese go to in the city. Service is great and I'm ready to try out basically everything else on the menu!
author: Priti K.

description: Really loved their spicy food, especially their big bowl of fish fillet soup with pickled cabbage. We always come here when we crave spicy food. Staff are super friendly and welcoming (two lovely ladies). Good portion too. We always ended up over ordering.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
I've been here several times and it's always been consistently good. The dishes are some of the most authentic Sichuan food you can find in the city. I ordered garlic pork, spicy fish, and green beans. They are all decent. Like most of the Sichuan dishes I had in the Bay Area, I wish the dishes could be a little bit less oily.

Sustainability comment: it uses large plastic containers for take out. Most of the time the size is an overkill.
author: Lynn S.

description: Meh. I've experienced better. Much better.
author: Sandeep P.

description: If you like Chinese food with an extra little bit of spice, this is the place. Order a few dishes to share, some spicy, some cool. Portions generous. Prices very fair. Prompt service with a smile. Consistently good. We take visitors from LA, Hong King and UK and everyone loves the fish dishes, the sweet and sour pork and deep fried red bean cakes. Worth the short detour from Clement St.
author: Demurrer F.

description: The service here was great the waiters were nice and we were seated right away but unfortunately the food was very very bland there was no taste to it, we ordered green beans, beef noodle soup and short rib beef. None of those items had any taste to it. If you know what real Szechuan food tastes like then you should more then likely stay away from this place. I'm not sure why the reviews are a 4 star but the food is worse then Panda Express!!!
author: Najma A.

description:
Ordered delivery last night through Yelp. When I got to the end of the process of submitting the order the delivery option was disabled.
I called the he restaurant, and they said they now only do delivery through the Postmates app. Ok, so I had to download that app and start over. When I checked out, there was a substantial fee added on by Postmates.
This was a surprise to me, but by that point I just wanted to get the food delivered. Sichuan Home needs to update their info on Yelp. Delivery is NOT free!
Oh, the food was just ok
author: Ken M.

description:
Great food ! 

The host was really lively and passionate about the food. We managed to stumble into this place as it wasn't planned beforehand, but boy was it worth it. Will come again for sure next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Henry O.

description: Food is delicious, affordable and service is amazging. This will be my go to place from now on for Szn food. Def get their fish dishes and the beef noodle soup
author: Kevin L.

description: I liked the beef string bean. The green beans were cooked for the right amount of time and the oyster sauce was great. I don't always love the beef like in many chinese restaurants it is greasy meat. I can't complain for 7$ for a lunch dish though.
author: Belgian D.

description: Not good , I don't know why, the Chinese restaurants in inner Richmond and inner sunset are just NOT GOOD! They are not authentic sze chuan flavors , and they are very dirty inside , I tried both Sichuan home and Szechuan cuisine , quite disappointed at both. People who have force star reviews are either know nothing about Chinese food or they just have low expectations.
author: Momo P.

description: I eat at Sichuan Home frequently and have tried many different dishes.  All are very good.  Chef Liu is a modern Chengdu chef and creates many of his dishes plus the standard Sichuan dishes.  The last time I ate there we had "dry fried lamb ribs with cumin" that was incredible and "short ribs with chili and garlic that was just as good.  They have a large menu that can satisfy anyone, not all dishes are hot and spicy like their smoked tea duck or dry fried string beans.   Try it you'll like it.
author: Bill P.

description:
This restaurant is amazing. If you are in this area, eating here is a must. The service here was amazing. The people here really made you feel at home right away, and, for me at least, the wait was only 5-10 minutes long. I got three dishes- spicy fish and chinese herb spice, dan dan noodles, and chef's special spicy pettitoes.

Spicy fish and chinese herb spice- 5/5
THIS DISH CHANGED THE GAME. Normally I an not a fan of spicy food, and of fish, but this dish made me experience what could only be described as a culinary orgasm. I should mention that I am very sensitive to spicy foods, but this dish still rocked my world. Even though it made the insides of my mouth burn hotter than the flames of hell (not really though, it was just a tiny bit spicier than hot cheetos), my tears were not of pain, but of joy. This is the best chinese fish I have had in my life (no joke). As an added bonus, the fish had NO BONES. This is a must.

Dan dan noodle- 4/5
This dish is good, but there's nothing really special about it.

Chef's special spicy pettitoes- 3.5/5
While I didn't enjoy this dish too much, it wasn't bad either. This kind of dish isn't my style, but if you like these kinds of dishes you should definitely get it. My parents loved it!

Overall, I would definitely recommend this restaurant to everybody I know, just for the spicy fish and chinese herb spice and the amazing service. The service couldn't be better, and if you come here, the spicy fish and chinese herb spice is a must.
author: Derek N.

description:
Having recently moved from philly to SF, I was really looking forward to more authentic Chinese food. Unfortunately I was wrong. This restaurant, with a 4 star yelp rating, definitely doesn't deserve it. 

The only dish I enjoyed was the cold dish - thinly sliced pork with garlic sauce. 

We also ordered their famous perfume fish and Ben Ben chicken and wontons in chili oil. Because everything is drenched in chili oil it all tastes the same.

The service was okay...but what I really didn't appreciate was the server kept telling me to order more and to order the expensive seafood dishes. For the two of us we ended up ordering way too much food and they didn't even tell us! They just told us to keep ordering. I felt like I wasted money on a meal that wasn't so good and have to keep eating it for the next few days. I DO NOT recommend this restaurant for people looking for authentic Sichuan food.
author: Rohenne L.

description: I have been sick all day today. The food must be terrible quality, I almost feel like I have food poisoning.
author: Alex G.

description: I use to really love this place. Food use to fresh, not greasy and actually delicious. Now, just straight garbage. I usually like to order their famous spicy fish ($26). Spicy? I use to tear up eating this dish, but now I can eat it without even tasting any spice. Beware too. They will try to up sell you and say if you pay a couple dollars more you will get fresh fish. First off, we got some nasty ass tilapia. Gross. Second, they charged us $38. Whatever. Their honey walnut shrimp was just clumped up with batter that you couldn't even taste the shrimp. Their A-Chou had some browning which was disgusting. Service is cool but only on the days we speak Chinese to them. It's ridiculous how big of a difference there is when you don't. I use to live for this place but now I won't ever come here again.
author: Ada H.

description:
I'm not a big fan of spicy food, and I am giving this place a 5-star?? You can tell how much I like this place.

Came on a Saturday night with 4 other friends. Not a big restaurant but not very crowded. Our server (lady boss?) was very friendly and didn't hesitate to spend time with us explaining items on menu in details.

#Crab Meat and Fish Maw Soup 蟹肉魚肚羹: B+. 
Wasn't planning to get this here since I don't think it's one of the Sichuan specialty food but my friends were so eager to get this. Taste was above average; I like the fact that they put a lot of those main ingredients inside, instead of a diluting soup like a lot of Chinese restaurant does.

#Chicken and Red Chili Oil 口水雞: B+.
This is a cold appetizer, have never tried this combination before (cold+spicy+chicken). It turned out okay. Chicken meat was pretty tender. The taste was actually slightly bland even from a person can't take spicy like me so if it can be a bit more chili oil it would have been even better.

#Garlic Pea Sprouts: A-.
Needed to order some non-spicy food as a balance. Fresh vege, perfect timing of stir fry.

#Chef's Specical Fish Stew: A.
Can't believe I am giving an A on this super spicy dish! The spic level was quite high, and to achieve that the chef put A LOT of chili and other ingredients inside. By looking at how much ingredients they put to get the taste right you know this place is legit. The fish deeply absorbed the chili sauce and it was super spicy, but I don't know why I could keep eating it (and keep sweating of course) there must be some special formula the chef used to make that chili soup, but yea it was super good.

#Mapo Tofu: A-.
This dish could be hit or miss - easy to make but if you don't pay attention to the details it will fail big time. And I loved how they made it there - heavy smell and taste, lots of red pepper and chili, and soft tofu. 

One of the very few spicy food restaurants that I actually don't mind coming back again and again. Need to try more of their dishes next time but the fish stew is a definitely must-get!
author: Simon C.

description: The dishes are rather disappointing and none of the dishes look as good as the pictures in the menu. The taste is just ordinary and the ingredients are not fresh. Do not recommend this restaurant.
author: Cathie N.

description:
Lives up to the hype! A coworker of mine recommended this place to me and I am so glad I took the 10 minute Uber ride out to checkout Sichuan home. Super fresh, authentic, flavorful, and just the right amount of spice! The spicy Sichuan fish was out of this world, the Dan Dan was tasty and savory, the Mapo tofu was appropriately silky with bits of salty pork, and the cumin lamb was tender and flavorful. My only complaint was the portions were generous and my dining partner and I had no place to take the leftovers!!

Very clean restaurant with a simple decor and incredibly friendly service. So glad to have found this place!
author: Rebecca M.

description:
This restaurant is a SCAMMER!!!!
This restaurant is a SCAMMER!!!!
This restaurant is a SCAMMER!!!!

Their receipt didn't show the detail of food at all, so they can charge you a lot extra sneakily if you didn't read your receipt carefully.

Be aware of the waitress speaking mandarin with Szechuan accent!!!

这餐馆是骗子！这餐馆是骗子！这餐馆是骗子！重要的事情说三遍

收据很简陋，不会写你具体order了什么，所以结账的时候一定要仔细看！！！所以结账的时候一定要仔细看！！！所以结账的时候一定要仔细看！！！

有一个四川还是重庆口音的大妈，会偷偷的算你的小费，而且一张收据上算两次小费。我有一句妈卖批不知道当不当讲？

菜不好吃，又油又咸，瞎几把乱做。祝你这狗餐馆早日倒闭，WCNMLGB
author: Peter X.

description: They served very authentic Sichuan spicy fish!  We also ordered the ChongQing fried chicken cutlets, which did not let us down!  Friendly staffs and very sensitive to customer's need.  The complimentary Shanghai dessert is another plus point.  Will definitely return to try out the grilled fish and some other dishes.
author: Sarah P.

description:
I hope I can give them zero!  We traveled to San Francisco, found this restaurant by yelp. I was surprised they can get four stars in yelp. Dinner is so so, the waitress kept recommending even we had ordered oversized foods. Absurdly their cashier was not able to read our Chase credit card, which was alright throughout the vacation, they even let us got cash from ATM nearby! 
Totally disappointed experience, only bad thing in our trip.
author: Peng S.

description:
Mmmm! My housemates and I were craving something spicy so we decided to give this place a try. We weren't disappointed - there's chili oil in EVERYTHING! We ordered the chicken in chili oil which was okay. The picture looked tasty but it came as a cold dish so we were thrown off. We also got this cold... bean jelly(?) as well. I liked it because it was covered in sauce and because I like the texture.  What I really enjoyed was this stew that consisted of asian spam, intestine, pork blood and tripe. Omg it was delicious.

Not to mention, their service was ON POINT! Especially for an asian restaurant... They were attentive and super friendly. Loved it!
author: Kenitha Y.

description:
The food is drenched in spice, so much that your taste buds burn off. Yes, Sichuan food is spicy but holy crap I could've just drank chili sauce and achieved the same results. They should just serve the sauce on a plate, because every thing tastes the same. 

The waitress kept pushing for us to buy their lobster noodle special, because "you'll only get this special price today only!!" No thanks, lady, I already said no twice. 

Mediocre service with less than mediocre food.  

Their shanghai dumplings are also store bought. Yikes.
author: Cass Y.

description:
This place is legit!!! My parents are Sichuan natives and they say this place is super authentic! Great tasting food with low prices! A must-try for those interested in authentic Sichuan cuisine. 

It's the little things but I also appreciate that they don't charge you for the tea. :P

Wait times: 5/5
No wait times at 5 pm on a Sunday. 

Taste: 5/5
One of the best Sichuan places I've ever been to and my family makes a point in finding Sichuan restaurants wherever we've lived. It's spicy but not inedible. Pretty tame compared to other restaurants I've been to but packs a good kick. Every single dish I've had here has been good.  

I recommend the Chongqing chicken, chilli chicken, and couple's delight. The chow mein is made with thick noodles, which surprised me since I was expecting Cantonese chow mein style but it was still very tasty.

Quantity: 4/5
Some of the dishes are a little smaller than I expected like the chilli chicken. But generally fair given the lowered prices. They also give complimentary pickled vegetables at the beginning of the meal and sweet mung bean soup for dessert. 

Service: 5/5
Very friendly staff who are attentive. 

Price: 5/5
$8-$12 for a dish.  Which is amazing given how good they all taste!
author: Alice L.

description:
My go to dishes here are "steamed pumpkin with pork ribs" and "pi pa tofu with broccoli", the place is small and not fancy, but the food quality is very authentic and to my surprise--the service is very friendly.

They are recommended for 1 Michelin star!
author: SJ L.

description: Good. Chinese. Food. My chinese mom liked it- she's not originally from the sichuan province but she can appreciate good sichuan food. The portions were huge, the prices low, and the flavors great! Just order the pictures on the wall.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Really great authentic Sichuan food! 

I am not usually a spicy food person, but the food here is pretty tasty and very filling. My friend and I each ordered a noodle (she got dandan noodle, and I got noodle pieces with pork) for $7 each, and we got a bowl of pig blood, intestine, spam and other interesting pieces for $12. Did not realize how big the noodle bowls were...It is definitely a lot for just one person. We barely managed to finish one bowl of noodles and had to pack the other ones to go.

Flavor wise, I felt everything tasted very authentic, and since the servers were speaking in the Sichuan dialect, I am assuming that the chiefs are also from the are. The dandan noodles were mostly noodles and not so much soup, which is perfect because you can eat a lot without getting full quickly. It had the right amount of spice and flavor, and definitely do-able for even someone like me with a weak stomach. The noodle pieces (basically lumps of flavor shaped like noodle) with pork was also very tasty. The noodle pieces were very chewy, and the pork pieces were cooked very tenderly. A must try for Chinese food lovers!

The dish with pig blood and intestine also did not disappoint. The bowl had all shorts of things (pig blood, pig intestine, he mu er, spam, korean rice cake...). If you were to order the dish alone, definitely get a bowl of rice. One tip, if you don't finish the dish, pack it home and you can mix it with plain noodles to make your own dandan noodle!

Service was very quick and servers were friendly. Will definitely go back sometime.
author: Wendy F.

description:
This place is SO good and worth the trip to the Inner Richmond. I made reservations for a party of 8 (complete with a lazy Susan because #Chineserestaurants), and the table was ready to go when we arrived. 

I thought all of the food was incredibly authentic and tasty. Of the dishes we ordered, some of my favorites were the dan dan noodles, dumplings in chili oil, Sichuanese fried chicken (with bone!), eggplant, and garlic pea shoots. I didn't try the pumpkin pastries, but I heard from my vegetarian friend whom we had ordered the pastries for that they were awesome. I was a little underwhelmed with their special spicy fish stew, though. Next time I come back, I want to try the classic spicy boiled fish.
author: Kelly R.

description:
The Dan Dan noodles are amazing and the soup dumplings ... WOW!! 

Cumin beef was over cooked and over spiced.

The customary dessert was not to my liking but at least I tried it.

Will try some different things next time.
author: JohnMichael B.

description: Just picked up food from this place for the first time.  It's literally inedible, I'm making my children a last minute meal because nobody should be eating this food.  Not sure how this has a four star average on yelp.
author: Jess L.

description:
ordered two main dish,  the material is total not fresh,  just some stuff stored in refrigerator, then took out and added some sauces. 
So cheap place, waste of money
author: Winson W.

description:
This place is one of our favorites!  Get the egg tofu dish.  And the twice cooked pork and mixed vegetables.  

The soy milk is delicious too!
author: Pauline W.

description:
My first impression of this place is so mixed since I had such a horrible experience trying to find parking just to get here! But of course I can't write a review based on parking because that's just not fair. 

But do be prepared to circle around a lot if you plan on coming here, or just park somewhere and take a cab/uber/lyft. It may very well be worth your sanity. I came here to meet up with some friends. The drive from the east bay took about 30 minutes, but parking took about 40. 

So back to my review... by the time i showed up, the food had all already been ordered... so I really couldn't tell you what we ordered since most of the items looked the same. From what I remember, the meats are mostly in some spicy red sauce with green peppers and chili peppers. There was a fried sweet potato dish which was quite tasty and a soy sauce chicken. I think 4-5 of the dishes after a while all tasted the same as they were all mixed up on my plate. I really did not know what i was eating after a while, but that didn't stop me none the less. 

If you like sichuan or just spicy foods in general, this is your spot. Last but not least, this place is tiny and the waits are long. We had about 15 people in a table meant for 10, which made it very difficult to eat. So be prepared if you are in a big group...
author: Milton F.

description: Excellent spicy and tasty flavors. Tried chefs vegetable, Spicy Fish & Cabbage, Spicy Chicken fry and Chowmein. All were good, wonderful!. Come back again.
author: Prakash M.

description:
"Best Chinese meal I think I've ever had" said my wife as we finished lunch.  Even my brother and his wife (SF residents for over 20 years) were impressed.  We were trying to find dim sum at 3pm on New Years Day (good luck!) and after striking out at our usual spots we walked past Sichuan Home and decided to give it a try.  We were all so glad we did!   They quickly accommodated our party of 7 (there are two large family tables in the rear of the restaurant) and we had tea and Tsing Tao beers flowing within a few minutes. 

Unlike a lot of Chinese restos in the area, the menu we were handed was in English and had lots of high quality pictures making it easier for the kids to pick out what they wanted.  The waitress was also very helpful, making SURE we got the tastiest dishes (that also happened to drive the check up nicely but they were worth it!)

Everything is quite spicy, so this is NOT the place to take your granny or small children that can't handle the heat.   But the spiciness is not overwhelming - the balance of herbs and other flavors is really well done, and I never found anything that was over-powered by the heat (unlike a lot of Thai places I've been!)

Our selections:

Pan-fried pork buns (bao) - tasty filling of pork and green onion with a hint of sweetness.  Much better than the usual sticky-sweet dreck you get at a lot of dim sum places

Soup dumplings - solid but not stellar.  (I'm spoiled by too many visits to Din Tai Fung around the world).  The dumplings had a nice flavor and the broth was good and rich, but they seemed to be filled about 1/2 way ("flaccid dumplings" my 15 YO son called them).  Unlike the ones you get at Din Tai Fun, these do not require a soup spoon to eat.

Kung Pao Chicken - as good an interpretation as I've had.  It's one of my wife's favorite "classic" Sichuan dishes and she said it was one of the best she'd had (lots of celery, onion, and bell pepper made it nice and crunchy.  Not too oily, with a great balance of heat and flavor with a light caramel-y sweetness.

Special Fish Stew (see pic) - this was a crowd pleaser and DEFINITELY something you should try.  It was more than enough for our party of 7 (along with the other dishes) and was absolutely delicious.  The pot is full of a rich spicy red broth with mung sprouts, glass noodles, and other herbs and spices, topped by about a pound of fresh fish fillets and Cilantro.    They bring it to the table on a gas burner and allow it to finish cooking for about 5 minutes at the table.   It is served with a slotted spoon for pulling out the chunks of fish. The flavor of the broth was a complete mystery to me - normally I can make out the predominant flavors in even complex Chinese or Indian food, but this was something so new and unique to me that I am still wondering about it.  Absolutely a MUST-TRY if you are a Chinese seafood fan!

Giant Clam Special - whole fresh giant clams are opened up, sliced thinly and then arranged back in the shells with tiny vermicelli type noodles and topped with a ponzu-like sauce and a generous helping of wok-fried garlic.   WOW.  Another AMAZING dish.  $7 each but worth every penny just to try!

Black Pepper Squid -  the kids love fried calamari, so we got this as a treat for them.  Everyone really ended up enjoying it.   Strips of squid (no tentacles) battered in a typical crispy light flour batter and then tossed in fried garlic and green chilies.   Another solid performance on a very typical Chinese restaurant menu item

There were a couple of other dishes, but these were the stand-outs.  Our bill with tax, tip, and SF healthcare tax came to about $180 for 7 people and we took enough food home for probably two more meals.

If you're in the neighborhood and want to try something different than the usual dim sum fare (and enjoy spicy food) definitely give these guys a try - the service is great and the food is outstanding.   We'll definitely be back!
author: Brent C.

description:
It's been widely accepted that there are 10 levels of spiciness. USFDA approved...sort of.

Level 1
So mild, it tastes like Strawberries Wild.

Level 2
"Would I offend them if I ask for a bottle of sriracha?"

Level 3
Aww that's cute.

Level 4
If you say this is spicy, people won't call you a sissy.

Level 5
"Let me get a double shot of Aquafina. On the rocks."

Level 6
Usher did say to Let it Burn after all 

Level 7
You just sit there pretending not to be hungry.

Level 8
Weather Channel: "This just in. Looks as if Adele has just Set Fire to the Rain."

Level 9
You are probably not going to look forward to your bathroom break later.

Level 10
You see Charizards everywhere. Are you hallucinating? Or is the image in the mirror legitly growling and doing flamethrowers in all direction?

I'm disappointed to say that Sichuan Home only falls under level 2, despite priding themselves for serving Sichuan (the region of China that's notorious for their tongue numbing spiciness) goods. The food was good, but not spicy. The chewiness of the Dan Dan Mein was perfect tho :)

Hey I dare you to ask them for a bottle of Sriracha. I double dog dare you to ask them with a cocky face.
author: Ringo M.

description:
I was super disappointed about this restaurant.
I am a foodie and Chinese, who loves Sichuan food the most. I have been searching good Sichuan restaurant in SF, and X&Y is the only one that meets the standard so far. I was happy to find this one, since it looked it has authe tic sichuan food.
Here is what happened about the food:
 We ordered about 9 dishes, from their signature Chili live fish fillet to delicate steamed xiaolongbao. I believe that the sample is good enough to rate the restaurant. 
First thing you will notice is salty !!!! I mean I am from northern China, who loves eating flavorful and salty food. But when saltiness is overwhelming, it's just bad. Overall the food is soulless and salty 1/10.

One dish they should never put on menu is 椒麻鸡 （maybe English name is chicken salad with Chili and peppercorn). What a shame!!!! It did not have any flavor from hot pepper and numbing pepper corn ). -1000000/10

And the chef special sauteed chicken ( 沸腾小煎鸡） is very salty too. It didn't have the Sichuan signatures spiciness at all. It's such an
over salty ordinary dish. 1/10

The live fish in Chili sauce ( 沸腾鱼）is a different story. The Chili sauce  looked very red and spicy. But u could taste anything flavorful and spicy when u eat it. It tasted very mild and flavorless. I had suspicion that the Chili oil sauce is reused, which sounds horrifying:(.  And the fish tasted fresh, which is the few positive things. 1/10

The braised beef with noodle ( 牛腩刀削面), i never had any noodle worse than this!  it's so mushy and soggy! it's the worse thing you can do to noodle!! The broth and beef is actually decent, but noodle is just too bad. 2/10

Cumin lamb, it was OK. It's just standard lamb, 5/10.

Xiaolongbao skin was bad, the same problem as the noodle. But the filling was not bad. This is also only thing I enjoyed eating, even though skin
is kind of soggy.   6/10.

Service was average. It wad little better than average Chinese restaurant. 

They have weird layout , you have to walk through the kitchen to use bathroom. It's not a pleasant walk for sure. The restroom had a disgusting odor , almost killed my appetite. 

I saw some Caucasian enjoyed their food , not the typical food we order. The table next to us ordered dumplings, fried rice, etc. I think for these general Chinese food, they might be doing OK. But when it comes to their so called Authentic spicy Sichuan food, I highly recommend you to go somewhere else. 

这家的川菜做的非常非常咸，没有任何辣椒花椒香味和神韵。 典型的不用心做菜的餐馆， 作为资深川菜Eater非常不推荐。
author: Pink M.

description:
I'm from Sichuan, and I tell you that this is authentic and good!!!! Fish dishes are always good picks, you can't go wrong on their fish menu. Cumin lamb is another one of my favorite. Chef Special chicken is good, and all my foreign friends always enjoy it too. Oh, their cold dishes on the first page of the menu are good too. 

Food portion is always good! And waitress are always welcoming and friendly. It is a little pricy compare to most Chinese restaurant, not a daily to go place, but I think it's worth at least once per week!
author: Timtim H.

description:
I think this is definitely one of the better Sichuan places I've tried in the Bay Area. We came here about 8p on a Friday night, and there was a little bit of a wait. I imagine at peak times, the wait gets kind of crazy.

I liked the service here a lot. The ladies were really nice although full warning that one of them tried to upsell us like crazy on their specials that day, like the Lobster noodles special. I heard her do this to another table too. However, we wanted to stick to the basics. I think you can always tell how good a Sichuan place is by gauging certain classic dishes: the Chong Qing chicken (spicy chicken) and the spicy boiled fish fillet most especially. 

We ordered:
- Chefs special fish fillet
- Spicy oil dumplings, or Hong you chao shou
- Dan dan noodles

This was a good amount of food for two people and we did not finish everything. Everything was certainly spicy! The dan dan noodles were quite good, very spicy and not super peanuty. I actually like that style more so it was good. The noodles were thin though and I wish they were chewier but that's just personal preference. I probably would not get this dish again so I could try other things on the menu but it was good. 

The spicy oil dumplings were decent too. Not the best I've ever had because the filling was not my favorite, but still good. The fish fillet though - oh man that fish fillet was really delicious and chock full of veggies (though we did add veggies). I'd definitely like to come back here and try some of their other dishes, like the sauteed frog legs in chili oil.
author: Lin Z.

description: As a local Sichuan person, this is the most authentic Sichuan food i can get overseas. I also love the services there. The staff are very friendly, truly feel like home whenever I go there.
author: Misha C.

description: The cumin lamb is really good. The place is small so don't be surprised by a short wait to get seated!
author: Alice S.

description:
I love szechuan food and I believe this is one of the best in the city...

We had been going to Z&Y and Chili House (which don't get me wrong, are great) but this has a more authentic feel and taste if that is what you are looking for.

Highlights (disclaimer: this is from the perspective of a "I Grew Up Eating This" Chinese-American vs. a "I Only Like Chow Mein" type of Chinese-American...):

- Boiled Fish
- Steamed Egg
- Lotus Salad
- Calamari

We have also tried the spicy chicken but there were too many bones.

Overall the food can be on the greasy & oily side but is OH so delicious!

Staff is also incredibly friendly (bonus points if you know Mandarin).
author: Adele Z.

description:
My favorite sichuan place in town is Z&Y, but this Sichuan Home is starting to win me over because of its home-style and the unpretentiousness. 

Service is super friendly (it helps if you speak Mandarin, or Cantonese because I heard some around the corner). We were seated promptly with hot tea served. Ordered 3 things:
- chef's special fish stew. They definitely tried to upsell us with the add-on veggies. We got the enoki mushrooms, which were super tasty and flavorful. The fish stew itself has great value - $18 for a gigantic amount, and lots of flavors, spaces, herbs, and very spicy for our request of "just a little spicy" version.
- the "little fries" which contains thin taro, potatoes and chives slices. Very special, and tasty. Taro's texture was a bit hard for me. 
- hand-cut noodles with pickled veggies and pork. Great value again (huge bowl for $7), and super tasty, warming broth, al-dente hand carved noodles. They split the noodle soup into two bowls for us, one with pork and one without, which is very sweet of them. 

For the two of us, we took most of the fish stew home as the portions were huge. That fish stew was also a great thing to re-cook and add all the veggies you want for a second meal. It was also quite spicy, but not numbing as this dish wasn't cooked with the numbing pepper. 

The meal came with a pickled cabbage and konbu (seaweed) appetizer. And a mung bean soup for dessert. Both great. 

One thing worth mentioning is Sichuan Home was on the Michelin bib gourmand list for 2013, 2014, and 2015. It's definitely a strong and quality restaurant in SF.
author: Wendy K.

description:
This is my go to spot for Chinese food in the Richmond. The staff is always very friendly, and the food is great.

I recommend the Sichuan chicken, mapo tofu and the fish stew.  All are my favorites!
author: Masa K.

description:
That is good and the food is very fresh my friends and I are very happy hereThe food here is delicious
I will come next time
author: Suman L.

description: Me and my friends went to eat Sichuan Home for very first time and Wow the foods were amazing, delicious and the portion of the foods was very generous. The staffs were very friendly and super nice. It will be in the list of my favorite spicy restaurants to go for sure. Definitely way better than the spicy house on clemet st.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
Ordered the chef's special fish and special vegetable.

Great flavours - neither dish is extremely spicy or salty. 

Great portions - definitely those couldn't fish those two between 2 hungry people.
author: Kehan F.

description:
I went there for lunch.  Last time I ordered the dan-dan mein which was pretty good.  This time I noticed from a "lunch special" menu taped on the window.  When I tried to order one of the dishes on that menu, the waiter said they don't have a "lunch special" menu anymore.  They should take it down if that's the case.

So I decided to order the chicken noodle soup because the photo on the menu looked enticing.  BIG BIG MISTAKE!  When the dish arrived it looked nothing like the photo.  There was barely any chicken pieces and some of the pieces were the chicken neck flattened to disguise it from being part of the neck. The chicken bones were fractured so tiny pieces of bone were dropping into the soup. None of the 5 chicken pieces were longer than an inch.  Definitely the worse chicken I've ever had.  I swear the chicken were the rejected scrap chicken pieces that didn't make it to other orders.  

I have to seriously think again if I want to go back there.  Definitely avoid the chicken noodle soup dish at all cost.

If I went back and ordered the dan-dan mein dish again would I be disappointed?  The dan-dan  mein dish that was so wonderful the other time I went there.  Stay tuned.  Maybe I'll go back just because they do have an extensive menu and just order what other reviewers raved about.
author: Acura Nsx T.

description:
This restaurant is located in Inner Richmond. 
I think that this restaurant is popular in this area. 
Because there were waiting many people at inside and outside.This is one of my favorite Szechuan restaurant in SF. 

(Rating: +++ is perfect) 

Atmosphere+:
Inside of the restaurat was like a Chinese style and simple.

Service+++:
 Quite polite, kind and friendly. Workers are so nice. 

Value+++:
Reasonably cheap!
_________________
Food

Fried celery and vegetables++:
It's not spicy and the taste was very mild.
When you tired some spicy food, you can take a short break.

 Ben Ben chicken++:
This dish was cold. 
There were some sliced chicken, peanuts and many peppers into the red soup.
It was quite a spicy.

Spicy BBQ+++: 
The spice was good balance. I couldn't stop eating although it was spicy.  

Sichuan style Mapo tofu+++:
This is my favorite dish in this restaurant. I want to need a cup of rice when I ate it.

Zhajjiangmian+:
This was not hot and the taste was mild.

Pot potatoes, shrimp, enoki and pepper ++:
The taste was nice.

I sweat a lot during eating but it is comfortable after dinner.
author: Hiromi S.

description:
I've been here many times, but took my parents here last night and just had to gush over my love for Sichuan Home.  One of the last remaining legitimate Chinese food places in SF.  The menu is extensive and I do suggest doing your research on what to order, but you can't deny that when it is good, it is excellent.  Food is served hot and service is "Welcome to my kitchen" friendly.

ALWAYS order: Chef's special fish stew, chef's special vegetable, wonton in spicy sauce

Cuttlefish is great, but can get mixed reviews at the table.  The dan dan noodles where too soupy for the connoisseurs, but the noodles themselves were fresh.  Lamb with cumin was delicious, the duck roll was also fantastic.

The szechuan tea smoked duck has great flavor, but is bony (and is meant to be).  Don't get this if you are confusing it with Peking duck.  

Overall, any misses are made up by the other fantastic dishes.  It gets 5 stars because it's true to what it is and can remind you of how good Chinese food was (pre-Panda Express and PF Chang's Americanization).  You know when all of the neighborhood Chinese people are eating there and ordering jellyfish, you found a good spot.
author: Karen W.

description: Fantastic! Everything was awesome. We tried the cumin lamb, fish pot, hot and sour soup, pork dumplings and mushroom and bokchoi veggies.
author: Billawdeep D.

description:
My recent dining experiences confirm stark contrasts of the culinary diversity of San Francisco.  Whether you enjoy fine dining, casual comfort food, or regional cooking, there is always something for your palate in the City.  
My uncle recommended this small neighborhood restaurant that specializes in Sichuan fare and invited other family members to a recent Sunday night dinner.  Getting off work a bit late on Sunday, I arrived to a table already filled with my relatives and food.  I munched from the various plates that were already served.  Here is a summary:

Good
1) Fish soup (requested not spicy) - Very flavorful and sweet, soft textured fish fillet meat in a clear broth.  

2) Xiao Lung Bao - (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=1kqiFhK_YPAI_biQ5SAzEw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) Not sure whether this was delicious because I was famished or the dumplings being served piping hot in the steamer.  There was a decent broth amount in each dumpling (ate two).

Okay
3) Twice Cooked Pork - Popular Hunan dish that had decent flavor, but not much character as everything was brownish.  Could have used some veggies to give more texture.

4) Szechuan Rice Cakes - (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=l1MzUcloh9PTf5PG9rxQTA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) Made spicy, the rice cakes reminded me a bit of elongated gnocchi.  Must eat while hot (temperature) as the rice cakes harden when cold.

5) Crispy Tea Smoked Duck - (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=ot7pGsqQUVy6kjoUd-z3mQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q)

6) Thai style Shrimp rolls - (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=fBZKgbU6N4GRWP5SNYkqaA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) 

7) Sliced noodle and Beef - (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Ezn9sKmoQlflanGPwOwG3g&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) Everything about this was very plain... meat, noodles, and broth.

8) Shrimp kebab in hot sauce - (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=9-Uk5UzpWkP5FStzsjI-fA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q)  Again, nothing memorable... flavor, texture.  Be careful when eating as the fluids in the heads will spurt upon biting.

My cousin who coincidentally is a fellow Yelper asked me about my star rating during the meal.  Being diplomatic, I told her that I wasn't sure yet.  The service was prompt and efficient as the dishes were quickly carted out in rather speedy intervals.  I added the rice cakes late in the meal and it arrived within five minutes.  The chef probably noticed the number of dishes that we ordered and generously prepared us a complimentary dessert of red bean paste pumpkin rolls.  One table ordered their hot pot and it looked interesting, but, like our meal, didn't look like anything particularly special.
Thanks, Uncle, for a decent meal... and sorry that you learned that they are Cash Only.  Be prepared people.
author: Mike C.

description:
I've never been disappointed here. I had the good fortune of ordering what HAS to be the best thing on the menu the very first time I went, and I've ordered it every time since. The spicy fish, a sort of stew or overloaded soup, is one of the best things on the face of the earth. Ask the waitress, she'll steer you to the right item.

I've also tried the beef pancake, and various fried and sauteed entrees. A few of these are strange, but mostly hey are also good, and that wonderful fish so overshadows any problems that it's a wonderful experience every time.
author: Jeremy C.

description: Good food, great service. I had the duck, the spicy prawns, the pork ribs, and the chicken chow mein.
author: Brenda A.

description: Quite tasty food with a broad menu with everything from Kung pao chicken and fried rice to brain and intestine. It's a bit on the pricey side for a Chinese place but is super tasty. We got the black pepper beef short ribs, which were amazing. Brea sauce and very tender. The Xiao long bao weren't very good with thicker skin and served on cabbage leaves... they also didn't have any real soup. The fish stew was amazing. Get the non spicy version and is spicy enough. The fish is super tender and really good. Definitely worth getting even at $18.95. Get that and nothing else if you have to since it's enough for two alone. Overall, solid place and very tasty, just not the most economical.
author: Phil D.

description:
Yes I waited 2.5 hours to eat at this joint on a Saturday night because everything that other people there were ordering looked fantastic.

I highly recommend going early during open hours, or come in around 8:30-9 when the bustle empties out.

This restaurant is so far the best authentic Szechuan restaurant I've been to. I had their spicy soup dish with fish inside where they bring out a portable stovetop to your table for you to enjoy the hot soup throughout your meal. Fried chicken is a MUST!!! It's cut into small pieces so you can enjoy as finger food- and make sure you get the bone in if you don't mind working a bit for the tasty chicken.

The star of the night (believe it or not) was the tofu broccoli dish. It's simple yet the best dish of the night. 

Come here for a casual night of amazing Szechuan food!
author: Sarah K.

description:
Even though this place is Michelin rated, it doesn't fully preserve the traditional taste of Sichuan. 

We ordered the spicy fish & Chinese herbs, mongolian beef & the fried chicken.

Entrees 3: The spicy fish was very numbing and didn't have enough spiciness but the fish itself was very tender. The mongolian beef was tender but didn't have the right flavoring. The fried chicken was more salty then spicy. I would've liked more chili spices, the type that makes you sweat & chug water, brought to each dish to really bring out the authenticity of Sichuan. 

There's only 1 restroom and it's past the kitchen on your left.
author: Willis L.

description:
Came here at 5:30 on a Wednesday night and we were the only table for a while before folks trickled in. This gave us the opportunity to enjoy the chef's singing, the two servers joining in from time to time.

As soon as we sat down one of the waitresses gave us menus and a complimentary appetizer of seaweed and chilli cabbage. We ordered 黃瓜， 擔擔麵 & 干煸四季豆 (cucumbers, dan dan noodles & green beans). The 黃瓜 tasted so good--crispy, fresh w/heaps of chopped garlic. Similarly, the 干煸四季豆 was really fresh & tasty, not soy saucey like other Chinese restaurants, and complete with whole chillis and garlic cloves (the dish comes with meat but I ordered it without). The 擔擔麵 did not disappoint. 

Nice ambiance, bright lighting, great food & exceptional staff.
author: M-E C.

description:
I liked the idea of this restaurant, but... nothing was spicy, even if there were two chili signs. Meats are low quality (lots of fat pieces or bone in it). 

Green beans with pork were not as crispy as you'd like

Service is slow but this is because the ladies usually are very busy. I've been twice and they've always been sweet and personable. 

First time they gave us a dessert, second time... none. Must have forgotten. 

Next time I'll go back to Spicy Queen, since something was spicy there last time...
author: Valerie L.

description:
I spent some time in Hong Kong and also lived in Arcadia California with over 70% Chinese population. 
Based on my experience, I would go as far as to say that this is the best Chinese restaurant on this side of the ocean :)


PS: I know Hong Kong is not same as Sichuan Chinese, but the authenticity is amazing.
author: Harout K.

description:
My favorite Szechuan restaurant.  Everything's packed with delicious, well-balanced flavor.  It's definitely a place where I know I could order something I usually don't like but end up enjoying it anyway.

Highlights:

Chongqing Fried Chicken: I order this at every Szechuan I go to and Sichuan Home has my favorite.  It's fried perfectly and has just enough spice to kick in that numbing sensation just a little.  Portion is pretty good and you can add fried green beans to the dish for $3.  Highly recommended.

"Chef's Special Fish": This is probably what I'd consider to be the specialty at this restaurant, and it comes in a few varieties.  Every time I've been here the fish has been perfectly cooked to be firm to the chopstick but soft to the tooth.  The broth is quite spicy but very flavorful.  Highly recommended.

As with most Szechuan restaurants you definitely need to order rice to temper the savory saltiness of the food.  Service isn't perfect but is generally friendly.  Prices and portions are about average.  Bring a hungry stomach.
author: Brandon W.

description:
I start coming here on a regular basis now. The food is awesome! I love this place. It's a nice change after have eaten in  many so greasy Chinese joints in the Richmond neighborhood.

The first thing I try when I go to a new Chinese restaurant is  Kung Pao chicken. Sure it's a classic but it will give you a very good idea how the kitchen operates and if they use the real wok which is my opinion is the key and the main reason why you wold go to the Chinese restaurant at the first place.

The wok is how here! It roars in the kitchen and the result is a tasty, slightly spicy and nicely seasoned food.

Some of the food I tried and really enjoyed: 

1. Kung Pao chicken.
2. Green beans with pork
3. Eggplant...classic
4. Pork in bay leaves.
 It does have a lot of chilly peppers and chilly oil and it is delicious. 

What I would skip is the fish dish... more bones then I like. 

The service is OK. Do not set yourself up for Gary Danko experience here. It's a simple family affair and I love just because of that.
author: Xela H.

description:
Best Sichuan food ever 
The owner is a Sichuan woman 
Sooooo nice and kind 
By the way, I comes from Sichuan
author: ShuPing W.

description:
This may possibly be the lamest review that I will ever write. I came here for dinner with my parents and their friends, and because we didn't do the ordering and my knowledge of Sichuan food is pretty limited, I'm not entirely sure what exactly I was eating. But here's my take--

The place takes reservations which might be a good idea if you go during a busy time--when we finished our dinner around 8pm, there was actually a respectable number of people waiting outside which definitely surprised me.
