The friends who wanted to come here are from Sichuan and said that this food was super legit and authentic. Maybe Sichuan food just isn't my jam because I really didn't think the place was that amazing? The food was fine, but I felt like at the end of the day, the food itself was pretty flavorless because it was spicy. I can eat spicy food no problem, but this food was just spicy--like the spiciness was the flavor. So if you don't find it actually spicy, then it's just like shoving bland food down ... so I wasn't a huge fan. Moreover, the spiciness wasn't the traditional ma la that you expect from Sichuan food at all. 

We got a variety of the fish dishes, beef tongue, lots of stuff. Like I said, this is a lame review since I really don't know what exactly ordered. 

tldr; okay Chinese food that really doesn't taste like anything...
author: Jasmine X.

description: I love spicy food as much as I love sweet!! This is my top choice for my spicy craving days ! Numbness , real hot peppers make my stomach so satisfied  although foods are a little bit too salty for me. I like ask them to make my food extra spicy when I order food. Lastly I love their FREE dessert green bean dessert. Perfect after mouth of spicy and garlic smell. I recommended many of my friends come here , they like it too.
author: Yan C.

description:
I come here all. the. time. Like 2x - 3x a week. It's really close to my apt, the ladies are always really welcoming and generous and the food is spicy and delicious and beautiful and lovely and spicy. I love spicy food. 

My go to dishes are always cumin lamb, double cooked pork, spicy wontons and the hand pulled noodle soup. I've tried their frog dish and fish stew, which weren't my favorite but the rest are solid and make up a good portion of my evening meals. 

That would be a 4 star rating....but what bumps this up to 5 for me is a dish I had never heard of before and was introduced to by the chef. It's a plate of freshly fried boneless chicken tossed with chili, garlic and scallions and the chicken is SO SOFT we all thought it was fish at first. The batter is light and crispy and I like to get it extra spicy. 

So ...basically I just gave 5 stars for the best spicy asian chicken fingers I've ever had. Give me a plate of these and an IPA and I am good to go.
author: Jonathan Y.

description: Food came out quickly, have big enough table to sit large parties. Their 麻辣香鍋was not quite the same as I've had in Beijing. Sichuan peppers should be much bigger. Their lamb cumin dish was good and the chongqing chk.
author: Diana L.

description:
The food came out in less than 5 minutes.
The flavors were good but not spicy at all. (which i expected)
The food wasn't that hot and it came out so fast that I was skeptical that it was fresh.

I liked the cumin lamb but I'm usually a fan of that dish.
The chef's fish stew was giant.  It wasn't spicy at all and could've been a tad more flavorful.
The cabbage in spicy oil was ok. I've had better.
The pork belly in garlic sauce was lukewarm. 
The Szechuan cold noodle wasn't bad either. 
The Shanghai steamed buns as they called it, (xiao long bao) were too sweet.  The skin was pretty thick and wasn't juicy enough.

I just didn't like how the food wasn't spicy and that the temperatures were off.

I don't know how authentic this place is since they have other dishes from different parts of China.
author: Heejin L.

description:
There's only one reason I order disgusting foods (tongue, jellyfish, blood, chicken feet, beondegi, etc.): it's because... wait for it... I want disgusting foods.

So you know I ordered the fried kidney. // They'd run out of kidney.

(After reassessment) How about rabbit? // Misprint. It's no longer on the menu.

Umm. Uhh. Lamb? // Finally, something in-stock. #winning #exceptnot

Because when we got home, it wasn't lamb - I'd been given pork.

That was after a drawn-out discussion on how, yes, I wanted the #89 Lamb & Basil Sauce despite the server repeatedly trying to steer me toward the more popular #88 Lamb & Cumin. The Chinese captions for both items had the characters for "sheep", so the pig switch wasn't a language misunderstanding.

Our dishes were SUPER OILY, except for the cross-sectioned chicken in broth. The bone-in sectioned chicken was visually novel, but it also presented sharp SHARDS OF BONE to deal with while chewing. I don't need to work that hard for just a drumstick.

I'd rather chop up an ice cream drumstick and have that for dinner - no oil, no bone splinters, no un-kidney-un-rabbit-un-lamb.

Somewhere between 2 and 3 stars.
author: Dan B.

description:
Spicy!

Bf gave it 3 1/2 stars, I gave it three.  Lobster noodles that the waitress recommended was a good deal, pricewise and tastewise.  Bf said he would go back again, I want to go back to try the tan tan noodles but that's about it.
author: C L.

description: Order 2 things to go because the ratings were great.  One is a dish that is suppose to have lily bulbs macadamia nuts and other nuts in it.  What I got was a stir fry that had almost no lily bulbs in it, 90 percent celery and about 10 percent peanuts and stale cashews.  Zero Macadamias.  Hopefully the 2nd dish isn't such a rip-off....
author: Rae A.

description:
Sorry to upset you guys, but I was pretty disappointed with the food. I heard so much promising things about this restaurant, but was left to come here sparingly. 

The restaurant is tiny and I had to share a table with another family. My brother and I came here just for one particular item: Chef's specialty Boiled Fish (supposedly extra spicy). Presentation wise looks exactly like how it should be; lots of pepper, spices and pretty darn red. I have my bowl of white rice ready to eat. Sad to say, this wasn't even THAT spicy nor numbing. The more authentic ones usually have that numbing aroma flavor, but this had none of that. They also put beansprouts and some glass noodles on the bottom (That's a first I ever had it like that). The portion was HUGE though. But yeah, sorry, taste wise I've definitely had way better.

I also ordered string beans with minced beef as string beans is one of my favorite veggie dishes. The beans came out to be another disappoint, too. It wasn't crunchy as it should be. Instead it was soggy and tasteless (supposed to be garlic flavored). 

Besides their "ok" food, I would like to give props to the staff for being very friendly and attentive though. They even offered my shared table a free order of "xaio long bao" (steamed soup dumplings). 

I suppose I will give this place another try to justify the 5 stars that many people gave this place. But for now, this one isn't on my yummy list.
author: Fiona L.

description:
For an Important Meal, Is Sichuan Home Restaurant worth the Gamble???

I tried last night and and LOST Big-time. 

I have gone to Sichuan Home many times and have always enjoyed the food, service and ambiance.
BUT THIS WAS NOT THE CASE LAST NIGHT!

CAN I GIVE ZERO STARS?????

THE SERVICE WAS THAT BAD! WORSE THEN BAD!

After waiting in line for 20 minutes outside my guest and I were next on the list.

BAIT AND SWITCH:
We were asked by the owner/Host if we'd be willing to "share" a rectangular 6-top table with the nice-looking young Chinese couple who had come AFTER us. We agreed because there would still be space between us and we'd have a semblance of privacy to enjoy dinner.

No sooner as we sat in the corner of the long table against the wall, the Owner/Host ask the Chinese couple, (who looked like they should be on the cover of "My excellent Chinese-American life") If they would like a Regular two-top table that just opened up.
The Owner/Host then Put a loud large group of three people ON TOP of my guest and I.

From then on, we were all but forgotten: 

THINGS THAT WENT VERY WRONG!

* We ordered the hot and sour soup to start and the Spicy Fish Stew as an entre.
  (We got the spice fish stew 25 minutes BEFORE the hot and sour soup. Which RUINED the    
  experience of the Hot and Sour soup, because the Fish stew is very good but too spicy to 
  precede the soup.)

* We asked for water 3 times and when it was finally delivered it was to the next table

* The glass of wine took two requests to be delivered

* Rice came after 3 requests, long after the appitizer and entre was delivered

The worst part of this whole experience was that it was completely avoidable.

TOTALLY DISRESPECTFUL AND UNCARING OF OUR DINNING EXPERIENCE!

* The OWNER/HOST was incredible disrespectful to us for not offering us the first open 2-top 
   the opened up right after we were seated.
*  It "Appeared" the nice Chinese couple were given the better table because they were 
   Chinese. (I am white and was dining with an non-Chinese Asian friend)
*  The OWNER/HOST decided on her own, (though we only agreed to share the table with two 
    people) to put THREE large loud young Americans at the table with us, where we just  about disappeared into the corner/wall.

The two groups at the big table were now being treated as one and the service was JUST AWFUL.
To top it off, we watched the "Chinese couple" get great service, all smiles and were eating their dinner before we received our drinks. 

REMEMBER WE WERE THERE IN LINE BEFORE THEY ARRIVED

The experience was shocking, lousy, insulting, rude, dismissive, and incredibly upsetting.

I don't know if I can ever recommend this restaurant again. I have not been this poorly treated in a long long time.

Michael S.
San Francisco resident for 20 years
author: Michael S.

description: Service and food are excellent. One of the best Sichuan food in the city! The Sichuan fish and sour fish dishes are my favorite. Highly recommended!  Oh love the soy milk too!
author: Mandy M.

description:
Service: great!

Food: delicious, well portioned, and yummy.

Environment: everyone: families, large groups, couples, and singles. I suggest you makes reservations for large groups of 4 or more because it's a small restaurant with long wait lines.
author: Kelli V.

description:
Discovered this gem the other day, and let me tell ya folks, Sichuan Home is legit. I walked in and felt like I was in China. I was greeted tentatively in Chinese, and when I responded in kind, the waitresses happily served me up hot tea and cold appetizers while I waited for my friends to arrive.

Definitely order the boiling fish and the dry hot pot. Can't speak for the other menu items, but their renditions of these two dishes are amazing enough to warrant a 5-star rating in my book.
- The boiling fish is tender, swimming in thick, spicy sauce that I dribbled all over my rice. Mmm.
- The dry hot pot with lamb, potatoes and lotus root is addictive and perfectly spiced. The lamb meat was the best I've had in America. (It's been tough and dry at other Chinese restaurants, but this one wasn't chewy or gamey at all -- just like in China.)

We also ordered cold rice noodles (great to start with, they arrive right away) and a separate spiced lamb dish (fantastic). My friends who tried the dry hot pot with frog weren't that impressed; apparently it's not as good as the one with lamb.

Only thing that wasn't authentic here was the service, as it went above and beyond anything I ever saw in China. The waitstaff were so sweet and gifted us free desserts galore.

Will come back to Sichuan Home again and again. My friends and I were talking about setting a weekly dinner date here -- yup, the food is just that good.
author: Tiffany W.

description: It was nice to get tea while I waited for take out. Everything was good- potstickers, green beans, sweet and sour pork, honey shrimp. The only thing is it didn't come with rice. I thought all take out Chinese came with rice. Is that an SF thing?
author: Maria T.

description: Almost everything here is extremely salty and not edible. Their beef pancake is OK but tastes like reheated food.
author: Qiang G.

description:
I'd never been here before today. Right away after I arrived the server brought me a complimentary salad of some sort with picked cabbage. It was tasty

I got the pan fried chicken with the bone in (bones are optional) and the pea shoot greens with garlic. The food was excellent. I'm not generally a fan of that spice that makes your mouth go numb (I don't know what this stuff is called). I don't like how it tastes. Well in the chicken dish it was used but with moderation. Most places I've been that use the numbing spice put way too much in and it overpowers the other flavors. 

Even though there was a lot of oil used in both dishes they still tasted light. 

The server was very sweet, friendly and accomodating.

At the end they gave me a complimentary cold sweet bean soup. I'd never had anything like it before and enjoyed it for its novelty.

All the other patron's dishes look fresh and very tasty. 

I'd come here again.
author: ellen c.

description:
Solid spice all around. We had the fish in spicy sauce and Chinese herbs, the squid, the cold noodles with chicken, spicy wontons, Shanghai dumplings, and hot and sour soup. I can say we didn't go wrong with any!

The fish in spicy sauce warmed you up from your chest to your head. The spicy wontons were very flavorful. The cold noodles with chicken had a spice with a delayed effect. And the hot and sour soup, while nothing to write home about, per se, was solid. I enjoyed the Shanghai dumplings but they were a bit oversized, didn't have enough soup, and could have had a more delicate dough wrap. 

If you're looking for spicy Szechuan, this is a good spot to go!
author: Art W.

description:
Wow.  Surprisingly good.  Funny how you can tell if a sichuan restaurant is good as soon as you walk in...because you can SMELL the spices in the air!  

I love the Chengdu stir-fry.  Definitely going back!
author: Kristen S.

description:
Food = delicious.  There should be a warning about peanuts, EVERYWHERE wherein applicable.  I ended up eating around the peanuts in various spicy dishes.  I usually avoid doing that.  :-(   

Bean jelly dish = delicious.  You have to like jelly, otherwise, this dish is worthless to you, as it was to the rest of my table. lol More for me!  (This was one dish that had peanuts in it, and nothing about peanuts on the menu!)

Sichuan chicken = perfect. Crispy outside but tender inside. Good flavor.

Pumpkin & Salted Egg Yolk = delicious, and slightly different from what I've had in the past.  Pumpkin was cut into strips, resembling fries.  It was a bit sweet, but definitely savory with the salted egg yolk. 

Szechuan Tea Smoked Duck = unique flavor. Get ready to gnaw on some bone, too. 

Fried pork intestines in spicy sauce = awesome.  Crispy but still full of flavor! 

Service = friendly.  Helpful, too. 

Prices = moderate.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Came here with a friend who is a regular, they greeted him right away and had a nice chat! Had homey feel right away.

We order special crispy chicken and kung pao shrimp - both were some of the best chinese food I've had in San Francisco. Not very spicy, needed to ask for extra hot sauce, so maybe ask according to your preference. The place is small and crowded and there will be some stressfulness among staff in getting you seated, but the food was well, well worth it.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Yet another excellent meal.  The food at Sichuan Home is really stellar, even if the service can be a bit inconsistent depending on the server.  

-  Spicy fish with pickled vegetables in soup - definitely our favorite dish and pretty healthy.  The fish was perfectly cooked, the pickled vegetables were a great complement to the spice, and the broth was delicious.  We even discovered glass noodles at the bottom of the huge pot that were great. 
-  Crab in chili oil - also delicious and appropriately hot. 
-  Fried chicken - tender and moist
-  Hand cut dao chao noodles - better when ordered as soup, was a bit bland relative to the other dishes, but the noodles were cooked perfectly al dente, lightly sautéed in soy sauce, and came with broccoli.   
- Pea sprouts - also a bit bland and not as good as the other dishes 
-  Chicken corn soup - didn't try this 

Cost about $29 per person before tip, although we ordered way too much food for the four of us and ended up finishing at most 2/3.   Overall we were delighted with our meal, again in spite of some very inconsistent service.   A reservation is helpful.  I also  recommend coming in a group so you can try multiple dishes.  The portions are HUGE.
author: Vivian W.

description:
It seems my older sister already wrote a review for this place, but I want to chime in too...

I really love the food here! 

Favorites:
Chili wontons! The wontons themselves aren't really spicy, but it's the soup. My sister and I can each have a single order all to ourselves, but it's definitely enough for 3 or 4 people to share if you order more food too of course. There's some choy (vegetables) in it too, but not a lot. It's a good combination of flavors. SOOO YUMMY!

Sticky rice cakes! They're good too. It comes with A LOT. Quite tasty and very filling. I wouldn't suggest ordering this dish unless you have at least 4 people with you or you will either have leftovers or not enough room in your tummy for other foods.

SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS! These are a must have! But, be careful. One time the pork inside wasn't cooked through all the way. The waitresses were nice enough to take them back and give us a new batch. They also gave us complimentary desserts too.


Although the ladies here are really nice, they have pretty bad English and only one of them speaks Cantonese. They're not very attentive either. You have to call their attention a good few times unless you get lucky really... But other than that, they're great.

COME EAT HERE! (I wouldn't recommend coming in large groups though. They only have 3 larger round tables. Most of their tables seat 4 and one of them seat 6.)
I go to school in So Cal, and when I come home, I try my best to make it out here before I head back down... That's how good it is!
author: Angie Y.

description:
Some serious authentic food and also lots of mild none spicy food. Basically a great place to get your spicy cravings out and bringing your non-spice eating friend along.

Some of the staff are really from sichuan. As for added spice / extra spicy for your Water Boiled Fish (the house special Shui Zhu Yu), and extra extra spicy for the new dry pot Kao Yu / BBQ'ed spicy full fish.

The silver noodle / Ants on the tree / Ma yi Shang Shu isn't spicy at all, caution 

The Dou Miao / Green sprouts and veggies are delightful, fresh and more canton style than sichuanese
author: Dilys S.

description: Pumpkin with egg custard is the best I have tried in the Bay Area! Spicy chicken is also authentic.
author: Yunzhu C.

description:
Went to this place after a friend gave me a list of Michelin recommended cheap eats restaurants in the Bay Area.

The Special Fish Stew was incredibly salty, more salty than sea water. Took some home to rinse off and salvage. Still too salty. Probably should have said something at the time, that is my regret. I can't believe someone would dish out such a salty mess.

Got the Lobster Lo Mein on special that day at the recommendation of the server. A huge pile of greasy noodles and a hacked up little lobster splayed around it, and not much else.

The flavoring is artless, unless you like salt.

You could get better food for half the price at dozens of places within a 10 block radius. I don't think much of Michelin after this experience.

The wait staff was friendly, I'll will give them one star for that.
author: Andy B.

description:
Searched hard for a Chinese restaurant in SF that had convincing good reviews. Trying to avoid American-Chinese food with generic sauces. This place was a winner. We went early (6-6:30pm) on a weeknight. Did not need a reservation. Almost all customers were Asian families and couples. Many people came, ate, and left while we lingered. No waiting line. Service was very fast. Prices were good. Only two complaints: the tea was made with teabags (!) and we had to ask four times to get steamed rice. Other than the rice delay, the service was very good and the staff was very nice to us. 

- Shredded Pork with Spicy Garlic Sauce - very tasty, with stringy black fungus (yum)
- Sichuan Style Spicy Chicken - amazing, lightly battered, boneless chicken, no sauce (I could eat this every day)
- Garlic Pea Sprouts - exceptionally delicious, fresh, tender 
- Dandan noodles - the least interesting dish (good noodles, but not much flavor in the sauce)

Small place, not fancy.
author: Mindy M.

description:
- food super yummy! And portion really large. 5 star
- waitress super friendly! 5 star
- gave us pumpkin pancaked and green bean soup for free. 5 star
- allowed us to use 3 cards (usually Chinese restaurant only allow one card ...)
author: violet s.

description:
Yum, what a great Sichuan place in the Richmond. Z&Y is still my go-to for spicy, numbing Chinese food, but this place is great if you don't want to trek to Chinatown (or Z&Y has a 1.5 hour wait!).

The service here is also way better. The waitress kept checking in on us and suggested food options. She was super friendly and attentive. The menu is also larger, so they offer dishes like hot & sour vermicelli with pig intestines that many Sichuan places don't have. Order the fish in hot oil - very impressive as they cook fresh, raw slices of fish in a big pot over a propane stove at your table. And the string beans are bomb!
author: Susan H.

description:
Hot.. Hot... HOT!!!

Don't come here if you can't handle spicy foods. 
I mean, you can still come & order the non-spicy dishes but I'm pretty you'll just end up leaving dissatisfied. 

Sichuan Home is most known for their spicy fish stew. 
Whenever my boyfriend & I have nasal congestion, we come here - it makes both our tummies & noses happy (two birds, you know). 
Yes, my eyes get watery & I drink craploads of water & tea because the soup is so spicy, but it's WORTH EVERY BITE. 
The broth is incredibly flavorful & they give such a generous portion of fish. 
There are also nice bites of seaweed & bean sprouts as well.

Today we gave their bacon in black bean sauce a try. 
It wasn't bad, but definitely on the saltier side. 

There's still sooo much we are dying to try there. 
But no matter what, the soup is ALWAYS a must!
author: Sylvia N.

description: The flavors are spot on authentic and just the right amount of spicy. Everything we got were super tasty and the ladies there are so so nice! My new go to sichuan spot!
author: Nana L.

description: Excellent service with authentic Sichuan food! The Hunan pork was so delicious! The fried green beans were also tasty and well received  We will be back!
author: Danielle M.

description: I love this place. Great food with great services. I enjoyed my dinner here with my Favourite spicy food. Very satisfying and full. They will help you take away if you can't finished it and dessert is complimentary. Really good place for spicy Chinese food. Authentic Chinese Sichuan Food. Thanks to them, I had wonderful dinner here on this Halloween night. xxx
author: Unyo N.

description:
Truly great food in a very clean restaurant!

The staff was very friendly.

We had the fish stew...spicey, tasty goodness
Also the dumplings were fresh and steamed to perfection
author: Patrick O.

description:
Solid food, although some dishes are definitely higher quality than others. 

My favorites are the Shredded Pork with Spicy Garlic Sauce and Sichuan Style Spicy Chicken (Boneless / Fried). Super tasty!

I was not a huge fan of their Beef Chow Fun (too many beansprouts and not enough beef) or their fried spicy chicken with the bone pieces in them.
author: Brett K.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and am definitely a fan! Great Sichuan flavors permeate through the restaurant. The menu is massive and decorated with many pictures of food that make you salivate. 

I've had some of these dishes-
- Chef Special Fish Stew: added tofu per hostess recommendation and loved it. Spicy! Lots of fish fillets and great taste.
- Spicy Tea Smoked Duck: very smokey but the duck was very tasty. Served with red chili peppers but not that spicy in my opinion. 
- Sauteed Lily Bulbs & Celery & Gingko Nuts, Cashew Nuts, & Macadamia Nuts: tasty veggie dish to accompany all the spice. Ample amount of nuts and greens. Very good.
- Chicken Wing & Special Sauce: very good! Crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside. Couldn't stop eating these.
- Pork Stuffs & Eggplant In Garlic Sauce: another veggie dish that offered relief from the spices. eggplant is cooked in long slices, which is something I'd never seen before.

The only thing I've tried that I recommend to skip is their Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai soup dumplings). XLB's is not part of Sichuan cuisine so it's understandable that they didn't taste authentic. 

Also wanted to add, the main hostess / server lady is absolutely hilarious! She is loud and always tries to upsell daily special dishes to you. She's very good and got us to add tofu to our fish stew dish, which we ended up liking very much. She's got a great personality though. I'd go back just to see her walk around and do her thing!
author: Jing D.

description:
This is pretty authentic and pretty good Sichuan food. The fish, the tofu, dandan noodles, and the beef (especially the fuqi feipian) are all very good, and generally any kind of Sichuan dish that you want can be found here.

The portion sizes are also pretty decent: my friend and I ended up ordering almost too much but since it tasted so good we managed to finish almost all of it.

This place is inexpensive, serves a lot of food, and serves it well. It's definitely one of the best Sichuan places in the city.
author: Alex Z.

description:
We made reservations & came here Christmas Eve at 8:30.... after watching a premier showing if the The Hateful Eight.  (You know just a typical reverent Christmas Eve with the kids.)

Like everybody else has written the food is awesome. A group of 7 having several different dishes everything was excellent. Two meat eaters 3 vegetarians & 2 vegans and we were all very pleased.  I had duck and it was crazy-good.

The folks running the place were so nice & the service was great,.Even though it was late Christmas Eve and they were admittedly in a hurry to close, we got full happy treatment.
author: Moon S.

description:
Went in today for lunch because of the raving yelp reviews, but unfortunately I don't agree with them.

I ordered the Kung pao chicken mild spicy , shoulda gotten it spicier. It was okay, except I wish they added the peanuts after cooking the dish because I like when they're crunchy, these were a little soft and kinda weird. The house chow Mein was good, definitely our favorite item. The beef short ribs were not good at all though ... Too salty and the texture was just off. I'm used to braised short ribs where they fall off the bone and these were more chewy. Def wouldn't recommend these. 

Needless to say we probably won't be returning.
author: danielle a.

description:
Service was INCREDIBLY friendly. Like the antithesis of every Chinese restaurant I've ever been to. The food was fantastic. We ordered the dan dan noodles, smoked tea duck, and kung pao chicken. All were incredible, and came out lightning fast.


Surprisingly not as spicy as I expected,but great balance of flavors. Excited to come back.
author: Patrick T.

description:
Sichuan Home. Looked like a decent place from the outside, walked inside, still looked decent. 

The friendly waitress seated us and passed us the menu. I ordered the Chefs Special Beef & Vegetable, Shanghai Dumplings, Special Vegetable Platter, & Chicken Fried Rice. The beef came out first. 

My dad can't eat VERY spicy foods so before we ordered, we asked if any of this was really spicy. Despite what she said, it was pretty spicy for him. We didn't complain because we understood everyone has a different spice tolerance.

Our second dish came: the chicken friend rice. Ehhh.... It was nothing special. It was pretty bland. We didn't even get our two other dishes we ordered. We asked where they were and the lady told us that we never ordered them?? Umm yes we did. But we didn't complain as long as she didn't charge us for them. 

We asked for the bill and we saw they added an extra item. Something that we didn't even order. I don't recommend coming here unless you are starving and are stuck out the front of this restaurant.
author: Emmanuella Z.

description: This is probably the best Chinese restaurant I have been to in San Francisco. We ordered the Shanghai dumplings, the fish soup, the pan fried chicken, and the spicy cabbage. The food was spicy, but it really wasn't overpowering. Everything is seasoned well and is just high quality in general. The prices are pretty reasonable too, considering how good the food is. I will definitely be back here, and I look forward to ordering new dishes next time (maybe the duck with a side of green beans!)
author: Andrew L.

description:
My friend treated me for Dinner on a Tuesday... 
All I can say about this place is that it's DAMN Good!!! The food was soooo Tasty and Spicy! That I couldn't stop eating!
I felt that I was in a LUST and couldn't stop Kissing/ Eating the food as if I was Kissing a girl for the very first Time! haha

Try this place Out! If you like spicy Chinese food... you got it Made!

The food is cooked perfect! No Super Greasy or Overly Salty.

I had the Chef's Special Fish, a beef dish that was served cold , a chicken pieces dish, and mayonnaise shrimp. 

Oh and the food went great with a Tsingtao beer.

Enjoy!
author: Alfonso C.

description:
Ordered the spicy fish and Chinese herb, snow pea leaves with garlic, and bean jelly in chili sauce (I think - boyfriend ordered this one in Mandarin lol). The portions here are huge!!  Between two people, we had about half of the fish dish and bean jelly to take home. 

The difference between that fish and the chef's special fish is that it has the ma la sichuan flavor (so we were told), which is really why you should be here anyway, so we ordered it over the chef's special. I wasn't too blown away by the flavor, but that could also be because we ordered it a little less spicy. It comes on a gas burner to keep it warm, with tons of fish chunks, bean sprouts, and even glass noodle. The snow pea leaves were also pretty standard, but what I really liked was the bean jelly. Again, huge portion with bits of ground meat and hard bean curd, it was sooo good.

Bathrooms are in the back, through the kitchen, so you can walk by and have a glimpse/smell of what they're wok-ing. Also, the service was super fast - all our dishes came out within 10 minutes.

My biggest complaint for this place would be the price. Even with the larger portions, I don't expect to pay $25 for fish. Chinese food is usually a lot cheaper!
author: Stella A.

description: My personal favorite lunch dish is their dan dan noodles spicy HOT. But of course I'm a dan dan noodle junkie, or simply a noodle of all form junkie especially for lunch. There must be 10 variation of dan dan noodle. This one comes in a brown chili sauce in the texture of a  gravy w/ a dap of chili oil covered w/ minced beef or pork.  Other variations are either in a clear chicken/pork broth, peanut sauce w/ coconut milk, or no sauce at all just w/ a meat veggie topping. Never been here for dinner & usually packed in the evenings when I past by.
author: Stevie C.

description:
I always get out sick of this restaurant, not because the food is not good, but because the food is TOO good and I can't stop eating.

We often have to wait and that's a not fun experience, the place is small and you have to sand by the door where is often cold and lot of people waiting. Well, that's the price to pay to eat good Sichuan food.

Price are reasonable, staff is nice, I got nothing to complain about ;-)
author: Sylvain K.

description: Beef pancakes, chow mein, cashew chicken, all delicious. Nine and thirteen year olds gave four thumbs up. A little find on a busy day in the city. We lucked out as we hear the crowds are often out the door.
author: Davy M.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night and only had to wait a couple mins. It's a small restaurant with prob about 8 tables. We were seated and ordered a meat appetizer, Chinese broccoli, xiao long bao and the spicy fish pot.  First they gave us a plate of seaweed and vinegar/spiced cabbage. Wasn't a huge fan of that but it's on the house! Meat appetizer was really good, perfectly salted with spices and vinegar. Chinese broccoli nice and crunchy. Xiao long bao was delicious however I would've enjoyed it more if it had more soup. The seasoning of the meat inside the bao was soooo good but it was just missing the soup inside... The HUGE spicy fish pot consisted of LOTS OF ENOKI (my fav!) some fat clear (too chewy didn't like it) noodles and also some of the thinner clear noodles, fish, prob some other veggies I forgot about and lots of numbing spices. We got it regular spicy as opposed to spicy or extra. Now my spice tolerance is pretty high and I think regular spicy was just perfect. If we had gone "spicy" prob wouldn't have been able to handle it as well. The fish resembled something like the consistency of cat fish but the fish itself was kinda bland..prob be better with the fried version of the dish.

The asian ladies who took our order was very attentive to our needs. She made sure to tell us on several occasions that the fish was ready (basically telling us to hurry the eff up and eat it otherwise it won't be as good) and when I dropped the ladle and made a splash she said "are you ok? "And "sorry" as she was walking by as if it were her fault (haha super cute) When she was taking away our empty plates we still had a couple peices of the broccoli on our plates and she was like "oh take your time eat everything" (typical asian mom) 

All in all I really enjoyed the food here and would come back to try other dishes! I love spicy foods!!
author: naviee P.

description:
The more I think about the meal I had here the more impressed I am. Following Patricia Unterman's advice (http://www.sfexaminer.com/sanfrancisco/sichuan-home-off-to-a-smashing-start-in-san-francisco/Content?oid=2179482) we ordered the spicy wontons (chili oil wontons), sliced noodle w/ beef (dao chow noodles), chef's special vegetable combo (lotus root, taro, chives). When the dishes came out I knew we were in trouble. The vegetable combo is huge. It's just piled onto a big serving plate. The spicy wontons come in a bowl for 2 (approx 15 wontons) and the sliced noodles came in an even bigger soup bowl. 

The vegetable dish was crunchy heaven. The taro roots had been sliced into matchsticks and then fried in such a way to be crispy and crunchy - like when you have taro root chips. It felt so healthy and light that it seemed impossible for it to be so tasty too. Probably my favorite dish.

The wontons were yummy and delicate. Went really well with the mildly spicy broth. Real Chinese soul food.

The sliced noodles and beef were super sichuan spicy. I'm not sure how they get that spiciness to permeate the beef because I didn't find any sichuan peppercorns in the bowl. Be aware that though it's "beef" it's Chinese style beef which is stew meat with assorted cartilage/tendons/etc. Since I like to chew on things this was fine by me but hubby wouldn't eat anything that wasn't meat.

Needless to say there was no way for us to finish all of this. We did manage to finish the wontons but had to take everything else home. Still yummy later.
author: Jean K.

description:
I don't love Sichuan food, but there are several dishes here that were really good! Plus, the menu is huge ( they also do hot pot) and they have pictures in the menu.

I recommend:
The hand made noodles with beef in spicy broth (there is a photo of this) page towards the end)
couples's delight
cummin lamb...

Unfortunately, the Shanghai dumplings weren't impressive. 

Also, don't go to the bathroom, the tiny kitchen (impressive how many dishes they have considering Taco Bell has bigger kitchen) that is questionably clean might freak you out after you just ate a nice meal there...
author: Phantom Of Yel P.

description:
You know how you go to restaurants and look at all the chef's specials on the outside of the window and think...man, only the suckers order these dishes?

Ok, I'm not actually sure if that's true or not, but you definitely have to order the specials that are listed on the outside.

Chef's Special Fish Stew: Light broth with plenty of veggies and fish.
Chef's special vegetables? Not sure if that's what it is actually called, but it's got taro fries, potato, and greens. So delicious. Couldn't stop eating it.

These two are definitely my favorites. Also got a chicken dish that almost seemed out of place since it wasn't spicy, but was delivered in a light broth with some excellent garlic/chili sauce. Also got a big "beer duck" pot that was tasty, but super full of bones.

Either way, this place is too legit.

The waitstaff was absolutely awesome. This is the place to go.
author: Andrew C.

description: Has become our favorite Chinese restaurant in all of SF! We take the long ride on the 38 from downtown because it's worth it. The dry fried green beans are out of this world, definitely my favorite.  I dream about it most days! Eggplant with garlic and pork is close second. It's more American Chinese but the Sesame chicken. . Wow best I've ever had. You can get authentic Sichuan or more Americanized Chinese but no matter.. They are all juat so good. Oh and great service! Love love Sichuan Home.
author: Vol T.

description: I live in Sonoma County so San Francisco Chinese food is a lot more "real".  Place is very clean, staff friendly.  We ordered the dishes that were familiar to us, but the menu offered lots of interesting options.  I am not a very adventurous diner, but I look forward to returning to try the seafood stew which looked amazing.
author: Cindy L.

description: Its our first time to eat here. We ordered salt  and pepper calamari and yangchow  fried rice.  We are very happy and the food here are the best...
author: Kristine R.

description:
Order the Sichuan specialties and this is by far one of the best Chinese restaurants in SF proper. Spent some time in China and to me, the mapo tofu had the right flavor, spice and consistency, the kung pao chicken sauce was great (though I'm always looking for higher quality meat), pea shoots were as expected, and even the shanghai dumplings were good. 

Service was delightful. Everyone was nice and food came out fast. 

Will definitely be back!
author: Amy L.

description:
My friend referred me to Szechuan Home so I decided to try it out today. The food was good, but it wasn't amazing. Compared to the Szechuan food I've had in the past, it's really pretty average.

We ordered:
Chef's Special Fish Stew
String Beans with Minced Pork
Watermelon juice

I had been craving fresh watermelon juice for a while, and was so excited to find out they had it! I definitely don't regret getting it.

They also give you complimentary green bean soup for dessert at the end of the meal which was pretty cool.
author: Vivian W.

description:
We wanted old school super spicy chinese. This was certainly the place to go. Right across the street from House of Bagels on Geary.
We ordered the cold tea smoked duck, spicy beef ribs with garlic and red peppers, spicy pork strips with jalapeno peppers and pea shoots. With two cokes and one beer it was $60.00. and we were stuffed.  Super spicy but tasty. The complimentary mild kimchee and kombu side was an excellent addition. Fast service. Very friendly. No after effect from the spice at all. Definately eat here. 
Everything was terrific except the weird barley and mung bean cold dessert that is complimentary. Tastes ok but mushy texture
author: Carol m.

description:
House special pan fried de-boned chicken- pretty good, avoid the seeds if it gets to spicy for you. comes with red and green bell peppers. 

Pea sprouts with garlic sauce- great dish to balance out the spiciness of the other dishes. next time I want to try the A choy dish with garlic sauce. 

We asked for a bowl of rice but it didn't come until the end of the meal, we tried to tell her we don't want it anymore but she didn't care. She just left it and walked away.

The end of the meal, they give you a small bowl of green bean soup. It was luke warm as if they took it from the fridge and microwaved it for 10 seconds and left it half cold.
author: Michael S.

description: Amazing! I almost gave up on Chinese food until I came here! I had the whole fried fish and it's was phenominal! I'm a fine dining chef and they nailed it!
author: Joseph B.

description: Absolutely delicious food !  The service was amazing.  Everyone was very friendly and accommodating.  The portion sizes are generous and packed with flavor .
author: melissa f.

description:
The worst food I've eaten on this 7 day vacation so far. Hot and sour soup, an item I view as a staple in most Asian restaurant was just plain terrible. All five party members could not stand the taste and or the awful is our it produced. The spring rolls however were great and well presented, cut in half which was perfect for our sharing needs.
The chicken wings although presented beautifully, were very bland and I would not recommend to foodies.
Took far too long to receive the water we had requested, although the service staff was very warm and friendly.
I gave this review a 2 star, based on the service of the restaurant pulling up the score from a 1 star food quality.
author: Ashish P.

description:
I love really hot food and I love sichuan food especially with tons of peppers and flavors. Plus I am really lazy and somewhat skeptical of Mission Chinese....it is in the mission (the parking is pretty wretched and the reviews have created a hipster haven....someplace I will avoid like the plague)

So it looks like it is just you and me Sichuan Home. Location....great...close....I can walk ....I like that.

First of all the restaurant decor is nice..no it is not tommy toys (thank god) and it looks pretty clean.

Second the service was pretty nice to me...I have read where some people say they are rude or slow...well yeah if they are busy and you are screaming at them.

Third and most importantly da food. I really like sichuan home food. I ordered for my friends and myself: The spicy tea smoked duck....omg what great flavors, yes a bit chewy different than traditional peking...but I like alot, ma po tofu (every sichuan restaurant should be judged on this) and their's is really good....spicy, hot, flavorful and full of layers...very good. I also ordered Fish Filets In Hot Chili Oil...very oily but still good.....fried fillets in a very spicy sauce. Finally I went out on a limb and tried the  Sauteed Lily Bulbs & Celery & Gingko Nuts, Cashew Nuts, & Macadamia Nuts ....yes only a vegan would love this. I will pass next time.

I like that this restaurant offers unique items: frogs legs, kidneys, trype, Chinese Yam Deep Fired Rolls  anyone???

If you are a vegetarian....I see you out there....they have an awesome assortment of vegetarian selections.

Prices are very good. 

I recommend you come when they are not crazy busy because service will get slow and parking is hell fri sat night.

If you have delicate stomachs...ask for the pepcid or pepto shot before hand...word up!!!
author: David G.

description: Really great food, very authentic to what you would find in China. Took my foodie family visiting from China here and they highly approve!! Would recommend everyone check this place out. I only wish I lived here so I can go more often, but I am in LA
author: Diana Z.

description:
As I made the U-turn on Geary, I was thinking Lou's Sandwiches, or perhaps a Ms. Vivian sushi roll from Ariake's, or maybe even hakka food at Dragon River. I decided to go with Szechuan instead...(nice list of choices all on one-block).

I went with the stir-fry lamb seasoned with cumin, onions, and dou-miu choy. The pepper spices were very mild. The lamb was soft and flavorful, tender without much game-taste. Oddly, this dish is listed as "fried lamb with cumin". I enjoyed this dish.

The platter of pork dumplings were good and solid; sorta average but still a-ok.

The complimentary cabbage appetizer was just not-good. It had this odd taste, that I can't really describe. Almost what dish liquid soap would taste like. The green-veggie-thing side-kick was so-so, but at least edible.

Decent looking menu worth trying for the next time.
...I'll stay away from their cabbage though.
...3.5 stars rounding up to 4.0
author: Derek N.

description: Great Sichuan food. Traditional establishment. Extremely clean restaurant. And service is outstanding - best of any restaurant in the area. Cabbage and seaweed complementary starter is s nice touch. Try the spicy fish soup.
author: Josh N.

description: I tried this place based on yelp reviews. But oh well watta unpleasant experianced. Food is just ok. I got raw chiken in my friedrice. My crab soup super bland. Service so awfull. Never ever wanna go back to this place. Yuuuuuuck is my opinion for this place. Sorry but not so sorry.
author: nita d.

description:
I love the food here. I am a huge fan of sichuan food and so far I haven't found a better place in the city. I like it better than the two popular ones in Chinatown (Little Szechwan and Z&Y). It's also got a much better small-size feel since it's in the Richmond.

Highlights: cumin lamb, princess chicken, and the noodle soup. mmmmmmm.
author: Ryan D.

description: Just had dinner here with my friend ,the food was just so so,The potatoes was too oily !!!  Other meal is just ok ! Little disappointed ......
author: Yi T.

description: The Sichauan style fried fish plate is to die for.  Even the veggies were still crunchy and not overly-sauced. This spot is good for sharing with a small group. Everything was delicious and not overpriced. Very authentic and really nice staff.
author: Katie D.

description:
If you like your food spicy, you gotta prepare your taste buds for SUPER spicy. lol just kidding. Authentic Chinese food run by Mandarin speaking people. Ohh yesssss. 

The food is definitely super spicy but you do have the option to customize the level of hotness. That's always helpful.

I can't remember the names of the dishes but let me describe them to you? Pardon my ABC-ness (my dad would kill me if he saw this review since he lived in Sichuan for a while...) but...

Fish Stew? Fish Soup? lol It's one of the main dishes that they advertise. You can definitely control the spiciness and even at mild, the fish is still somewhat nicely flavored with the spiciness. Bean sprouts, mou-er (pinyin check??) and some other veggies were in this stew. All in all, the fish pieces were delicious.

I also really like.. the clear.. tofu (or were they yam threads?) pieces that were drizzled in yummy spicy oil along with cucumbers. Oh my goodness. It's numbingly amazing and just goes greatly with rice! 

I can't say I'd recommend anything else at this point, but I'll work harder on remembering what the actual names of these dishes are. 

The only bad thing is that when this restaurant is busy, the servers.. No matter how nice they may be, end up forgetting water and rice requests. Understaffed? Perhaps.
author: Susan Y.

description: The staffs are super friendly and customer service is great. I ordered a veggie chow mein and asked for it to be made mildly spicy, but it turned out to be too spicy so they remade the noodles and gave me a new plate. Overall, the food is decent and will come back because the service is good.
author: Tiramisu W.

description: I loved the tofu and broccoli.  The sweet and sour pork was boney, but tasty.  The hot sour soup was delicious.
author: Sergio H.

description:
This is a preview review, as I've only visited once. I could imagine this restaurant earning 5 stars in the future after I've sampled more of the menu. 

I arrived at 10:06 PM after Outside Lands, and I expected them to be closed already, since 10 PM is the posted closing time. However, they seated me, and then another couple groups after me up until about 10:30, so I suppose the real closing time depends on demand and how the staff is feeling on an individual night. This earns them points in my book, because some Chinese restaurants stop seating a half hour BEFORE the posted closing time, which I find infuriating. 

They brought out a couple "banchan" like items to the table when I was seated. I believe they were seaweed and a mildly pickled cabbage. This isn't typical at Chinese restaurants, so it was a welcome gift. There is also complimentary tea, as you'd expect. 

I asked for recommendations of the spicy, Sichuan specialties of the chef, and the server ticked off some of my classic favorites, such as Szechuan Style Spicy Chicken (La Zi Ji, but boneless), Sliced Beef in Hot Chili Oil (Shui Zhu Niu Rou), and Fish Fillets in Hot Chili Oil (Shui Zhu Yu). 

When she mentioned the Spicy Tea Smoked Duck, and I knew I had to try it. The duck is smoky, almost ham-like, and it is bone-in, so there is a lot of picking around involved in the eating. If you enjoy La Zi Ji, then this is up your alley. In this case, the duck isn't breaded, but it is stir-fried in the wok with fresh green and dried red chilies, a well as ginger and garlic. It's wonderfully spicy and savory. My only complaint is that the duck was tougher than expected--I don't know whether it is always this way, or if my dish suffered because I ordered it at the end of the night. Only ordering it again, earlier in the day, will tell. 

I had expected to also order Sichuan wontons in chili oil (Hong You Chao Shou, literally Red Oil Folded Hands, here called Wonton Soup in Hot and Spicy Sauce), but then I saw Xiao Long Bao (here called Shanghai Style Steam Bun) on the menu. If you know me at all, you know I'm obsessed with XLB, so I had to try them here, even though this is a Sichuanese restaurant, not Shanghainese. The XLB were average, but not outstanding. Most critically they were short on the rich, unctuous, umami flavor that life-changing XLB possess. Next time, I'll try the Hong You Chao Shou instead, which I also love. 

Service was attentive, even though the staff were eating their customary end-of-the-night meal. 

Prices are great, a little less than other Sichuan spots like Z&Y in Chinatown and Sichuan Fusion in Richmond. 

Next, I need to visit Sichuan Fortune House in Pleasant Hill, and then I can finally determine which "Sichuan [living establishment]" restaurant reigns supreme in my spice-lusting heart (and tummy).
author: Chris Z.

description:
My friend was cravin' seafood and I wanted something spicy, so we decided on this place.  It's a pretty small restaurant and parking in the area sucks (since it's by all the restuarants on Geary).  We came around 830 on a Saturday night and we didn't have to wait more than 5 minutes for a table.  The waitresses were all really friendly and made sure not to rush us out even though we were still eating passed closing time.  

Overall, the food was really good and the service was impeccable.  We had the fish pot (which is enough to feed like 5 people), the pan fried pork intestine, and some dumplings.  Everything was good, especially the pork intestine (if you're into that kind of stuff!).  

It'd recommend going with a bigger group so that you can order more and try a variety of stuff!  Also, this is a Sichuan restaurant, so expect most of the stuff to have some sort of CHILI or SPICE to it!  YUMMM!!!!
author: Jae W.

description: The food here doesn't taste as good as they looks. There are too many good spicy food restaurant in sf. This one doesn't worth a visit. Trust me, the food isn't worth the price. The waitress keep pushing me to order the expensive version of the dish I ordered. Super annoying. Bad experience. ：(
author: Nancy H.

description:
Great food and spicy!  
A total mom and pop type shop, with fantastic food.  I've eaten here many times and every time it does not disappoint.  Prices are reasonable.


Decor: 3
Food:4
Service: 4  

Would I go back? You bet your pastrami I would!
author: Kelson H.

description:
I really like this place. The service is quick, the prices are decent, and the portions are big. 

The dishes weren't too spicy, but it had the perfect about of heat. 

The XLB-very flavorful, but skin a little thick.

Green Onion Pancake-very yummy and crispy. 

I love their special vegetable dish. It has a mix of taro and greens. 

The salt and pepper spare ribs was very tasty.
author: Karen H.

description: Bad taste, especially the fish, not fresh, the rice tastes like expired. weird atmosphere
author: Fanfan L.

description:
1. Low quality food, Fish were not cooked well, Double cooked pork is not authentic, 
2. Services were bad, forgot to bring water, forgot to give complimentary dessert, 
3. At the end, asked for cash to pay,
Very disappointed.
author: Bo M.

description:
Walked in here based on Yelp Reviews. The place is on the small side with a couple of oversized tables that would good for larger groups. They sat us there initially until a table left and we got moved on to the smaller table. 

The menu was quite extensive with some interesting items, we settled on the Cumin Lamb, a fish dish that is apparently a speciality, the string green beans and some Dan Dan noodles. Overall the food was pretty good. They served the fish dish in a huge pot that sat on some sort of stove to boil and cook at our table. The spiciness was just right for my taste. The lamb was great, the beans could take a bit more seasoning.

The service was alright nothing amazing... The restrooms on the other hand were subpar... You had to go through the kitchen to get to them.. Tiny little thing that's unisex... Not very clean... Ick.
author: Tania H.

description:
My friend and I were walking around trying to find a place to eat. Originally, my friend and I looked up a place on yelp that was next door but was closed. Luckily it was or else we wouldn't have been able to try this place! We were so glad we were here instead.

My friend and I are broke high school students but wanted something delicious to eat. We had about $25 to spend together. We ordered the House Special Chow Mein, Shang Hai Dumplings, and Spicy Wontons- all of that came out to be around $20, rest of the money we had we gave as tips. Pretty decent for the amount of food that we got, and all were very delicious with great flavors! We were both full by the end of the night. 

We were highly satisfied and service was great. We will definitely come back again!
author: Linh H.

description: I ordered the fish stew for dinner and had the worst stomachache ever. I was sweating profusely all night long! I would give them 1 star but since the server was so nice to me and my husband, I had to add another star.
author: Vianca M.

description: 很好吃的吃饭！麻婆豆腐好想啊！This place is spotless...literally. The restaurant owner really keeps this cute little place looking great. I was shocked and extremely impressed by the quality of the food. The flavor of the dishes (we ordered boiled dumplings, dan dan noodles and mapo-dofu) were authentic. Having been to the Sichuan province it's really hard to find food that parallels. This restaurant had charm, spicy food and terrific service, what more can I ask for? I will definitely be back!
author: Cindy G.

description:
The food here was great. Having traveled through Sichuan some years ago, I must say that this is the only restaurant I have been to outside China that serves up real Sichuan cuisine. 

But be very careful if you have children, as the restaurant (depending on what you order) brings out scalding hot, spicy dishes, sometimes in large pots to cook on your table. If that thing comes crashing down on someones lap, you will be heading to the er. I don't recommend this place with small children or unpredictable adults.

Very very tasty food. Very nice staff.
author: El Z.

description:
This place was A-DORE-ABLE.  Not because of the decor, but because of the smiling, playful ladies who serve you food.  I came in to eat alone after a long run through the presidio, and one of the ladies was very motherly toward me... we ended up watching korean soap operas on the tv together.  

At first I was a little intimidated by the menu.  The menu was beautiful.  One of the best menu's I've seen.  Every single item had a big beautiful photo.  It was very helpful in deciding what I wanted.  

The dish I really wanted was spicy oysters, but the photo showed the oysters swimming in a sea of red hot peppers.  That scared me off... I've eaten asian food too many times when it was too hot to enjoy.  I got the chicken instead.  The chicken came out covered in red peppers too!  Scarey... but it actually wasn't too hot at all.   It was actually perfect.  It was boneless chicken.. and as I ate through the large pieces, I started to discover some wonderful little extras in the sauce.  Whole garlic cloves, roasted soybeans... nice little touches.  

I was so inspired by the menu, I'm going to have to come back here at least 10 more times to try things out.  What I was impressed by the most was how many unusual items there were on the menu.  I LOVE trying new things... and this place has plenty of them.
author: Eric N.

description:
Spicy fish stew. That's all you need to know about this place. It was like $26 USD and it was worth every penny! It's my fav Szechuan dish and theirs is by far the best I've ever had. You guys in SF are lucky to have them!

Fantastic service too!
author: S S.

description: Lucky me Sichuan Home is within walking distance!  Love the spicy cabbage and seaweed complimentary appetizer/condiment.  I've enjoyed everything I've tried.  Especially partial to the Chef's special warm vegetarian salad - so crunchy and tasty.  A perfect place to bring guests who've never tasted authentic Chinese food.  The kitchen is willing to prepare dishes not on the menu.  Lovely staff.   Generous servings.
author: Tree C.

description:
Ever wish you could un-see something? That's exactly how I felt as I saw at my table looking into the kitchen seeing some of the workers playing with their hair and touching their clothes. One guy dropped a whole bunch of utensils and picked them right up, placing them back into the tray. Yes...I know restaurants are dirty but it's another thing when you're sitting their eating and watching this happen right in front of your eyes. Also, I think it's a huge health violation to allow customers to go through the kitchen to use the restroom...something is wrong with that.

On to the food...We got the Twice Cooked Pork, Spicy Chicken, and Shanghai Dumplings. The food was good. Everything had a little kick and wasn't too spicy, however, I kind of wish they were a little more spicy. My only reservation is the amount of meat they give you vs the ton of veggies, but that's my own preference..I guess.
author: Kevin H.

description: As I walked in I asked if they had some type of rice plate special to go. There must of been a language barrier as the lady sat me instead. I decided to roll with it, and ended up ordering the spicy chicken with a side of rice. I was immediately brought a bowl of seaweed salad with other leafy veggies, it was a bit oily but tastey. A few minutes later I had a large plate of fried chicken with garlic and red chili and side of steamed rice. The chicken was very crispy and had a very good flavor, similar to your typical salt and pepper chicken.  Then after my meal followed a complimentary dessert of Mong Bean Soup. I'm was not a big fan of dessert but it was a nice gesture. Despite the language barrier the staff was very nice and quick service.
author: Manuel D.

description:
I'm Asian and it's been hard to actually find good sichuan Chinese in the bay. This is very suprising since I expected chinese food here to be amazing.   East coast had a lot more authentic and better selection.  Maybe the hipsters ruin it aka mission chinese.  

Anyway,  this is my go to restaurant.  Their dishes are unique, spicy and just flavorful.  I loooioove their chive and lotus root veggie dish and their spicy fish is amazing!  Don't tell the hipsters....shhhhhh
author: So S.

description:
Solid four stars from a white girl. I don't know traditional Sichuan cooking but I do know what I like and this food was tasty. Service was fast and efficient, prices were decent and portions were very good sized. I will definitely be back.

Salt & pepper calamari: they nailed it on the batter, crisp, flavorful & delicious. I recommend.

Kung Pao Shrimp: another win! Shrimp were plump & delicious and the dish had good flavor. Wasn't spicy to me but I also didn't eat the peppers!

Veggie Chow Mein: very nice noodles and good veggies, not overly flavorful but that is standard for this dish, I would order again.
author: Cec D.

description:
The place was empty the entire time we were here for lunch on a rainy Wednesday afternoon.  No lunch specials on menu :(

The daughter loved their spicy fish. I was shocked how pricey it was compared to other restaurants in the city with similar item.

They only had white rice. We wanted brown.

The onion pancakes were awful.

The service was super sweet and fun and nice.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
I'd give more stars if I could! 
Amazing food.
Amazingly friendly people.
Amazing prices.
'Nuff said
author: Kevin G.

description: Everyone in san francisco has their favorite Sichuan spot. A buddy brought me here and boy was it good. Their infamous chefs special fish was mouth-numbing and watering at the same time. Also the eggplant.. so hot and sweet and derirshush.
author: James L.

description: Might be best Chinese food I have had in the City. Great service,  lots of different dishes to choose and great new flavors. Highly recommended!
author: Rebecca B.

description: A nice Sichuan restaurant in sf! Their food are actually not very spicy! However, the flavor is very good! I like the lady who served us! She is very helpful and friendly!
author: Li L.

description:
I'm ridiculously mindblown by Sichuan Home.
The other and I was running around and looking for a place to eat on Geary but some places were closed or crowded and we weren't planning on waiting since this was while SF was still charging for metered parking on Sundays. We stumbled upon this place and I was immediately like we're doing this because I want spicy. Now.

Ordered the fish and tofu in spicy sauce (it was completely drenched, so almost like a soup), a cold spicy noodle dish and a chow mein.

We started with the spicy noodle dish, which was a good palate opener, I thought it was pretty good but nothing super notable. Then we had the fish and tofu, which is quite possibly one of the best things I've ever tasted in my life. My mouth was burning and all I wanted to do was put more in. The flavor was sweet and coated my tongue nicely. I wanted to just put everything in that sauce.

Like the house noodles. Chow mein, pretty standard fare, not too shabby but with that sauce, one of the more enjoyable things I've ever had!

All in all, spicy lovers owe this place a visit!
author: Winè C.

description: Authentic Sichuanese food. The owner is super attentive and cater to our requirements of food. Do ask for her recommendation - she will point you to the hidden gems on the menu. Even the free pickled cabbage is finger-lickingly good!
author: Fei L.

description: Came to try the spicy fish, and was disappointed.  We've been in China for the past 15 years, and it's far from authentic.  However, looking at the positive reviews, seems frozen fish fillets in a so-so sauce can satisfy locals here.  We will keep looking, but this won't do it for real Sichuan spicy food.  The waitresses were nice, and told us we can order live fish (with bones) as the case with real Sichuan spicy fish......oh well, maybe next time.
author: Dennis K.

description: Very good dim sum place. Food is tasty! The only thing is you order your dim sum and they bring it out to the table. The food is fresh but it can take long. So if you want some type of bun, (BBQ pork bun, egg yolk bun, etc.) make sure you order them first. They can take 20mins to make!
author: Thy M.

description:
Here's the fifth star for continuing to surprise us with delicious creations (not just mind-numbing hot stuff, as other places serve) of unusual combinations, and Aileen's service that goes the extra mile.

Had green string-beans stir-fried in olive oil last week, and it was outright delicious, and quite daring for a Chinese restaurant! Bravo to the Chef!

Simple request: Can we please change the picture of Provence or Toscana hanging at the entrance? It is so not fitting into this place!!!
author: Wolfgang S.

description:
Amazing! I love this place, both the food and the actual place itself. 

I do the veggie-fried rice and the veggie chow-mein and they're both amazing!
author: Mike P. A.

description: This place is the best. Very spicy but full of robust flavor. They have non spocy dishes to and offer fresh made fruit drinks as well. The staff is super friendly their is a parking garage a block away.
author: Ashton V. M.

description: I was pretty disappointed when I went there today. I order a shrimp and scrambled egg chow fun and a spicy wonton. The chow fun was pretty bland, and for some reason my noodles were hard in places. The wontons were covered in oil and weren't spicy at all (I can't eat very spicy food so that's saying something). Both dishes also came out warm-- not hot. The waitress also kept on talking to her friends from another table, and did not notice my friend and I until we walked up to the counter. She also gave us the wrong amount of change. Overall, I would not go back.
author: Gloria C.

description: The dandan noodle is the worst I have ever tried in bay area. Not good at all! The fried rice is also disappointing as hell! Maybe other dishes are good but I will not go there anymore.
author: Lin Y.

description:
This place is good for Sichuan food. Nice chef special fish stew. 

The service here is very good.
author: Kiet C.

description: The food was nice. But I found a 2-inch cockroach climbing right under the pot. Not  recommended.
author: 梦菲

description:
My aunt wanted to come here for lunch so we came as a group (6 of us) today. Most of the food was really good. Very flavorful! We asked for the spicy foods to be mild because not all of us could handle it and it was just right. A few dishes weren't that great but I'll just keep in mind not to order those next time. 

My favorite dish was the chili wontons. They were mild but very juicy. It comes out in a bowl so that it's dipped in soup the entire time. Although the wontons didn't have much meat in it, I didn't mind. They gave us a lot more than I had expected from the looks of it. I would definitely get more of that next time. 

My least favorite was the bun that was fried (don't remember what it's called in English) because it was very oily and the filling's texture was not pleasing. 

This is a small place so I wouldn't come here with too big of a group  but it's a nice clean place. Presentation of all the food was lovely. They have nice dishes and even some bamboo dishes/holders for some of the food. I like that they try. 

However, I wish they would have given us bowls for the dumplings. The dumplings usually have soup or liquids that drip out and so my plate was just filled with the soup and such. I feel like that interferes with the tastes of the other food. Other than that, no complaints! Good place! Food is affordable and reasonably priced. I'll be back again soon!
author: Connie Y.

description:
Not an authentic Szechuan style restaurant at all with pretty mediocre quality ingredients. Their spice level is really low to almost non-existant. Even though they use the correct Romanization of the region of food they supposedly serve, this place just was throughly disappointing.

We got hui guo rou, which tasted really bland and didn't even use good cuts of pork, but just used mediocre rump (bacon) cuts. Then we tried their Dan Dan Mien, which really was just noodles cooked and bathed in hot oil. Finally, we tried their chicken wings, and it just tasted like regular chicken wings bathed in MSG and had a light dash of spices. None of this was impressive or a dish that I couldn't have made better.

The servers were incredibly friendly and even gave us a green bean dessert soup in the end, which was really nice of them, and shows that the restaurant means well, but the food just isn't there at all yet. If you want more authentic Chinese food, I suggest going to Irving or Clement just down the street.
author: Alan H.

description: The food here is pretty amazing! I had their chow fun with shrimp and egg, and I liked how it wasn't swimming in gravy.  I also got to try some fish in a spicy broth... It was so spicy, but really delicious!  I'd love to come back here again.
author: Vira P.

description:
We ate here last night for the first time, and it will be our last time coming here.

First, we had reserved the table for party of 5. We ordered like 5- 6 items including 1 order of rice. The server was nice but he forgot our rice and when I mentioned with the girl server but she still didn't bring us rice. Our server also spilted the water to our table but it wasn't a big problem to us. I understand that sometimes accident may happened. 

But the worst part, when my husband and I ate about  20 mins or so, we both had a smiliar symptoms like headache, facial pressure or tightness,  and numbness on the cheeks. I wasn't sure what was happening to me, until my husband asked me what I was doing, cuz that time I was massaging my cheeks and tried to yawn all the time. Later we realized that those symptoms were Monosodium glutamate (MSG) Symptom. It took me about another 30 mintues for my body to get rip off it. I've kept drinking and drinking a ton of water. I made myself to throw up as much as I could. This symptoms never happened to me before, I told myself and my husband that we shouldn't come back here if we want to live in healthy lives.

I know there are still so many resturants that using MSG but this place was the first that got me really sick, and I felt that my life was in danger. Lucky to my husband that he hadn't had a bad side affect like me.

At the end, I let you decide...but for me...Life is too short ( to die for MSG)
author: Sasitorn O.

description:
Can't believe I haven't written a review for my go-to restaurant for take-out.  Let's start by stating that I am Chinese, the kind that actually grew up and spent many adult years in China.  This restaurant is as authentic as it gets for Sichuanese food.  Caveat: they do have some not-so-authentic dishes geared towards folks that prefer what I call American Chinese food.

Talking about Sichuanese food, there're three key ingredient: MA, meaning tongue-numbing from the Chinese pepper corn), LA, meaning hot spicy from the chili pepper, and TANG, a lot of temperature hot oil.  This restaurant's got all three right.  The ladies working there told me that their chef was from Chongqing, a major food destination in the Sichuan region, so there you go.

Dishes I normally order and like: Twice Cooked Pork (Belly) & Taro, Wonton In Hot And Spicy Sauce, Shredded Pork & Garlic Sauce, Sliced Beef In Hot Chili Oil, Pea Vine & Garlic...all very delicious.

The ladies here were all very nice to me.  I might be biased though since I did speak Chinese to them all the time and I'm a regular that they know well.
author: Elaine H.

description:
I'd definitely return here. I've eaten quite a bit of Szechuan and they're my #1 choice so far in San Francisco (LA has better ones).

They start you off with cabbage and seaweed, which is absolutely delicious. Make sure to order the fish stew on the stove and the friend chicken. You won't regret it!

Make sure to ask for more napkins as well since you'll be sweating quite a bit. Pricing is very reasonable $26/person.
author: Albert K.

description: We had the spicy fish, garlic eggplant, onion pancake... All of it was very good with big servings, had to take about 1/4 of it to go. Most notable was the extremely friendly and inviting staff!
author: Megan H.

description: I've lived in Asia most of my life, I've been to China, and I feel like I know authentic Sichuan when I taste it. If you're looking for that in SF, this is the place.
author: James R.

description:
I don't know a ton about Chinese food by my friend who lived in China was with me and LOVED it. 

She ordered in Chinese so I don't actually know what we ate but the dish with eggplant was so amazing. The spicy pork was also really good and they end with a weird sweet rice pudding type thing. Overall a great experience - bring friends and eat communal style for sure.
author: Emily S.

description:
I wanted to write a glowing praise of a food place for a while and finally I think I found one. This is a potential five star place. I am holding one star just so I can award it when I see the great experience to be a consistent thing at this place. The place was clean, the waiting staff was great and the food was amazing! It really felt as if they really put a lot of care into designing their dishes.

We ordered the pancakes, Twice cooked Tofu and fried potatoes.  All the dishes were perfectly made and very well presented. In addition, I also asked for some hot chili and they got a concoction of Chili, garlic and herbs in oil; which was very flavorful and added an extra dimension to the food. 

Can't wait to go back to this place again..hope this time we will be equally lucky and find a parking spot fast!
author: Ravi C.

description:
First of all, I even can't describe how bad their service is by words. I always eat out but I've never seen such bad service at any restaurant. If I can rate 0 start to them, I'll do it without any hesitation!

They have a dish called "spicy fish & fragrant Chinese herbs" in the chef's recommendation. And it's marked as $25.95! This definitely is a very high price in a normal Chinese restaurant. I'm curiouser why it's so special for customers paying this money. So I asked the waitress, but she couldn't give us any opinion and said it's just good and push us to order it. I also asked the price of one dish on the wall(I didn't see it in the menu),  she even said why I always looked at the price in front of my friends,and asked them to never be my friends anymore(even though it was a joke which still made me embarrassed. For God sake, as a customer, of course I need to consider the price and I have the right to do so! And the dish turned out is ok according to my experience eating Sichuan food. 

When we were almost done(but we r still eating) it's not 10 yet, a waitress came over to ask if we finished and ready to clean up, she said they close at 10. But as I know, their ad post Saturday and Sunday their close time is 11. Under her pressure, we decided to checked out and leave, but we wanna the rest to go. However, they waitress showed very reluctant to do so. She even stirred my food with chopsticks and said there was nothing( actually there still was some, otherwise we wouldn't want to trouble.) 

There was something even worse. After we paid, my husband still had the receipt next to him but we were still talking. The waitress actually grabbed it away across him even we were still there. The first thing she did was to open it and see how much tips we gave. So impolite and rude!!

As several times I've eaten at this restaurant, I found they always showed more attentive to whites, and if you have more ppl and order more food, they like you more. As customers what we want is comfortable environment and service. But I'm responsible to say they treat customers unfairly and the service is the worst of the worst!!!
author: Qifei Q.

description:
The first thing I want to say is never let reviews discourage you, unless there are TONS of one star reviews, go out and try something new ! 
Thats what my wife and I did the other day when we went to Sichuan House. From what my wife said, this place is always full when she gets off work.
So we decided to get there. Right off the bat,  my wife isnt into spicy food, and NOW she knows what Sichuan aka Szechuan Chinese food is.
Okay fine, practically everything in the menu was spicy, which to me is not a big deal- depending on how spicy it gets. What made it interesting were the types of dishes, the chef must be eclectic and very experimental because there were a lot of unique dishes not seen at other Chinese restaurants. It was fascinating to read and look at the pages. 
There was a small section on the last page with traditional non spicy food if being cautious to spicy food is a priority...
We ordered Egg Rolls - basically your basic veggie eggroll and were good. 
My wife ordered Crispy Duck, okay that was simple enough. Or was it. Besides meat there was some kind of peanut butter filling that turned the dish into a duck pie. It was very filling, it was pretty good. I guess the peanut butter was included to due the lack of duck meat. 
I ordered something that was kind of like Kung Pao Chicken, but it wasnt, more like a big brother. It was fried pieces of chicken (hopefully) with peppers, peanuts and some small pieces of I think were meat or tofu or both. All of this was on top of a bed of red chili peppers. The chef must have poured the ENTIRE bag of chili peppers into this dish. They had no flavor or bite to them which I suppose is a good thing so I can taste the food. It wasnt bad, but also nothing special. We also got the Yang Chow Fried Rice and this was disappointing. It smelled and tasted like it was salted fish which I cant stand, but it was probably the tiny shrimps. I felt it was lacking something, and the smell of it was more of *no thanks* than a "come and get it" 
Overall I thought it was average based on what we tried, there are probably other things I might or might not try if we go back. This is definitely not your typical Chinese restaurant and some of the dishes will depend on your taste. For me it was okay but it did give me a middle of the night digestive issue, some lovely indigestion and then some.. good thing I didnt have work the next day.. 
The service was great overall when they werent playing on their smartphones...
author: David S.

description: At first this place didn't look very good but we ended up going since no where else was open. This was so good. I am glad we went.  The sesame chicken was the best I've ever had. Chow main noodles and beef were delicious as well. I would go here all the time of I lived here. The waitress had the best customer service and gave us a home made lentil soup that she said is healthy and it was a little sweet and so good to.
author: Lindsy C.

description: Good General Tso's chicken and great Kung pao chicken. friendly and welcoming staff.
author: JP S.

description:
When I ate here, when I left...I didn't think I was going to write a 1 star review, but a reflection of the agonizing service plus getting food poisoning led up to it.

The red chili beef was in a pool of oil. It was ok, not great, not bad.

I took a bite of the kung pao chicken my gf ordered and was like NOPE....NOPEEEEEEEEEE

(tasted like chicken had gone bad)

gf was like wat? its coo. (nomnomnomonom)

gf later going to bathroom every 5 sec
