me feeling under the weather but not as bad as her.

the vegetarian chef special with taro tastes good at first, but then gets old




the service.....I've heard through the times that some chinese tend to "talk loudly" and aggressively, almost as if they are fighting.  So many times I'm like no way they have to be fighting, but for example one time asking my chinese friend who was around he's all no, they were actually having a casual conversation.  

Well these two girls were shouting back and forth at each other like lunatics the whole time we were eating, look I'm not even one to complain about noise AT ALL, even when I'm trying to sleep. But this got damn right uncomfortable. I was expecting at any second one of them to strangle the other. This didn't occur, but at least that would have made things more entertaining than awkward.

Also, before they started "fighting" (or having super casual conversation that sounds like fighting) my server girl was sitting on her laptop the whole time. When I needed her I'd look at her, but she was jus chillen at a table on her laptop (while she is the only server in the restaurant).

Finally when it was time for our bill, she brought it. I gave my card. Then she returned it without running my card. Then had to wait 15 more minutes since she was on laptop for her to actually run it.

In the end the whole experience made me have a bad taste in my mouth, literally and figuratively; resulting in the 1 star.
author: Belito L.

description:
Good restaurant. Ingredients seemed fresh and tasted fresh. Just were not spicy enough tho. Ordered spicy chicken 重庆辣子鸡 and spicy fish 沸腾水煮鱼, none of them was spicy enough. Since the restaurant theme is spicy, I expected it to be very spicy. I understand people have different standards of spiciness, I wish they had different levels of spiciness for each dish for the customers to choose.
Anyway, overall a good restaurant. Bathroom is in the kitchen, so I was able to visit their kitchen, which was very clean.
author: Lisha J.

description: Great Sunday lunch. Sesame Chicken, Broccoli Beef, Shrimp and Ginko Nuts all perfectly done. Friendly service.
author: Bernie R.

description: The ingredients were not fresh.  The pork in the dumplings and the dan dan noodles had a smell and after taste to it.  The chili sauce in the broth was also stale.  Had these dishes many times at other restaurants, and this time, at Sichuan home, was the poorest.  I give it one more star for the cleanliness of the place, the food was really sub-par.  Will not go back again.
author: F K.

description: Hopefully we caught them on a really busy night; the servers were overwhelmed, so we felt a bit neglected. That said, the people who work here are exceptionally nice. The food is fantastic (except for the pan fried chicken which was so full of bones that each bite was a chore). I will be back, for sure. One more cautionary note - one which the restaurant owners will hopefully read - the bathroom, accessible via the kitchen, was super dirty.
author: Morris R.

description:
Most authentic chuancai (Sichuan style Chinese food) I've had in San Francisco. Better than anything in Chinatown, including but certainly not limited to, a particular restaurant on Jackson named after letters at the end of the alphabet, hands down.

Staff is super polite and food is excellent. Definitely worth the wait if there is one!
author: Samuel G.

description: Decent place, nice restaurant but the food was not that good and it was quite oily and wasn't quite spicy as we were told it would be.
author: Harsh S.

description:
Sichuan Home is a gem amongst many subpar Richmond Chinese eateries. Small, yes, but big on flavor! Personal favs include the beef and noodle soup, the Sichuan fried chicken (bone in) and the pork spareribs with breadstricks. They also do hot pot, though we've never tried it.

The staff are friendly and love to give recommendations if you're unsure which way to go. 

As the name states, this is Sichuan cuisine, and it is spicy. But unlike so many places where spicy merely means mouth-numbingly HOT, SH's fare is delicately flavored with many shades of star anise, chili peppers, peppercorns, and salt. It's an unbeatable flavor profile: hot, but bright notes that tempt you to eat more... and more... and yet MORE, until you, like Louis CK, don't stop eating when you're full; you stop eating when you hate yourself. 

Thank you, Sichuan Home!!
author: just-t H.

description: Hands down the BEST Chinese food we've eaten. Authentic and delicious. Service is superb. Very accommodating for my MSG allergy. Would HIGHLY recommend eating here. We decided to become regulars here.
author: Xing V.

description: Absolutely delicious, my Girlfriend was born and raised in Chengdu and she says the food here is authentic, all i care about is that it is delicious, cheap and the portions are big. If you like spicy you honestly cannot go wrong here this is a bi-monthly spot for us.  The Cantonese stuff is good but why would you get that stuff at a sichuan place anyway?
author: Charles W.

description: Horrible service. Just don't waste your money at this place. They can't speak or understand English and they get the orders wrong all of the time. We had to wait outside for 20 minutes before we got a table and they couldn't even give a glass of water without being told 2 times! They even tried to charge full price for something that they screwed up on. Gave no tips whatsoever. Never come here.
author: Om S.

description: This place has great pictures on the menu and Don't expect your food to look or taste like it. Good marketing but other than salt, oil and artificial flavoring, this place really need to up their game in  cooking good and tasty food.
author: tiantian l.

description:
This place lives up to the hype.  Awesome food, great service, reasonable prices.  Huge portions so it's tempting to order more than you need but the food is soooo good I don't regret it.    

They're going to try and upsell you but that's ok, that's their job.  Order what you want and enjoy.
author: M W.

description:
Seriously folks, don't even bother coming here if you're going to order American Chinese food.

+ So we had the Chef's special veg combo. Better than last time.
+ Twice cooked pork and taro. Just as good as last time
+ Chef's special fish stew. Pure awesomeness
+ A jelly/agar-type dish in spicy chili oil (don't know the name). Also seriously awesome
+ Pea shoots in garlic. Good, but kinda boring.
+ Beef noodle soup. Very good.
+ XLB. Filling was good, fair amount of soup, skin too thick, served without spoons and they were quite busy so I manage without one and managed to avoid burning my tongue. Good, but probably won't order again from here.

I've already decided that I will always order the chef's special veggie combo and the twice cooked pork and taro when I come here. If there's enough people, the fish stew and the jelly/agar dish as well.
author: J K.

description:
Very good restaurant. The food was good and big portions. The prices aren't bad either. The total bill came out to be $50 for four people. Like most restaurants, they can't be excellent at everything. Some dishes are better than others. You just have to know what to order. For example, their fried fish is decent, not great. We ordered the chicken and corn soup, stewed fish, dumplings, cabbage, and spicy bean jelly. They made it mild, but still had enough spice to make me sweat.
The service is standard Chinese restaurant. They can come off rude or abrupt, but it's a cultural thing. Every time I waived them down for water or napkins, they come over.
I look forward to coming back here again.
author: Calvin M.

description:
Stumbled upon this place when the sushi restaurant next door closed by the time we got there. What a serendipitous find!

Interior was clean, service was friendly, and I appreciated all the pictures on the menu as I am not too familiar with Szechuan cuisine.

The food was spectacular! Good portions for the prices, too. We ordered the cumin lamb and the silky tofu with broccoli. Flavors were absolutely amazing. Robustly delicious on the lamb, and delicately delicious on the tofu dish. The food came out really fast, too.

Definitely will be back!
author: Keli B.

description:
We order almost the same thing each time (and we go almost weekly):

Mabotofu (best we've ever had)
Cabbage and red peppers
Chicken (fried) and red peppers
Chicken corn soup

We'll try the pan dish everybody seems to have next time.
author: Patrick K.

description:
I have passed this restaurant few times. 
Today I tried the lunch.   I ordered the chicken noodle soup. It's was very tasty. Their noodles are home made. For dessert I had the Pumpkin sesame rice cake. Yummy. 
I saw their dinner menu. Looks good and reasonable.  The lady waiter Ana is very friendly and efficient. I like her. 

Lulu Huang
author: Lulu H.

description:
Flawless Presentation & Flavor without having to go to Sichuan China,
Reasonably priced. Tantalizing to the palate. Pleasing color to the senses.
Uncompromising unique & genuine ingredients cooked with delicacy & originality.
Small space but alert & attentive staff. Go & enjoy amazing authentic entrees

Yelpers, Think on this:  
How difficult & how much effort is required to attain status as a fine restaurant?
So support this city gem generously & remember to compliment the staff & chef with praise and appreciation.
author: Kenny C.

description: Fantastic service with a smile. These guys know how the cook well and treat their customers great!
author: Dinesh S.

description:
Went there again tonight - I think we did a better job of ordering because I was even happier than before. Got the Chef's special fish stew (extra spicy), which was excellent. Might be a good idea to ask for a bowl with this to make it easier to eat.

Also got the pan fried chicken (or something that had a very similar name) ... my new favorite dish. It's definitely going to be a must order for me every time I go there (it was an improvement over my previous favorite chinese dish which I've been looking for everywhere after getting to San Francisco)
author: Karthik K.

description:
While visiting China last year, we decided that the Sichuan Province was our favorite when it came to food. Ever since, we have been looking for a restaurant that can take us back there and now we have found it in Sichuan Home.!
 
Spicy Fish & Fragrant Chinese Herbs - white Fish fillets served in a soupy hot pot with lots of red chili pepper. The fish didn't seem too spicy. We turned off the flame within a few minutes after our waitress, Eileen, set it on the table. The fish was perfectly done.

Steamed Chicken & pepper sauce - good dish to offset the fish..

chongqing deep fried chicken w/roasted chili - for anyone who loves fried chicken..

Chef special veggie combo - love the taro root that is stirred fry with a few other veggies... there is a pic of it in the menu... get dish to offset the spicy...

Spicy smoke tea duck.. I wish I could have eaten more of this... the skin was delicious because it was crusty...

Pea spout with garlic - another great veggie dish

Eggplant and sweet garlic sauce... yum.. especially if you like garlic..

OMG, what a great idea... steam spareribs in like a light black bean sauce steamed in a squash. The squash was delicious especially with the juice of the spareribs melted into the squash... we just used a soup and scooped out the squash

6 orders of shanghai steam buns because they were just so so juicy and good..

diced chicken w/diced veggie in a lettuce cup

shanghai style new year cake- they use the long roll noodles instead of the flat ones, but still yummy..

Shrimp Kebah & hot pepper sauce - was compliment from the house because we ordered so much... delicious, they were actually giant prawns

There were so many more dishes we would have loved to try... definitely going back...
author: Jay S.

description:
I have to confess that I personally know the owner before he opens this restaurant through another friend of mine. But it is the reason why I stopped by this restaurant to try it but I tend to be very neutral when it comes to my rating of food. The environment is cozy, and the food is good. The quality of their food is consistently good and truly authentic since I know for a fact that the owner is from Sichuan. Lol.... My personal favorite is spicy fish filet, but this is a bit on the more pricey side compared to other similar restaurants. My boyfriend's personal favorite is the deep fried chicken sticks (I forgot the name on their menu.) But it was very crispy, easy to eat & very very tasty. This is also a specialty dish that can hardly found somewhere else. 

I am from southern China, and I used to hate eating spicy Sichuan food as it is way too hot and it hurts my throat. But this restaurant is my flipper. As I started coming to this restaurant, I gradually open up to spicy food. I totally fall in love with spicy Sichuan food. I still can't take sour spicy food like southern Asian food though. 

Another reason why I support this restaurant is the hard working work ethics and spirits of the owner. This is a typical family run business. The husband is the chef who works 7 days a week, and wakes up 4 am in every single morning to pick the freshest ingredients for his dishes in the local markets. The wife works as the waitress and cashier. They have not taken any day off since the day they opened this restaurant over 2 yrs ago. I sometimes think they are the superman/superwoman. I asked the owner why he won't hire another chef or assistant. He said it is very hard to find someone who would has the high requirement on the quality of food as he does. He wants to make sure every customer walk out of the restaurant with a big smile on their faces. He just can't risk the food to anyone else. I truly admire their ethics to deliver the best to their customers. No wonder every time I went, they always have big smiles on their faces. They just simply enjoy what they are doing. Anyway, best luck to them.
author: Gogo W.

description:
This is a very authentic little szechuan chinese restaurant. I generally eat szechuan food once a week in flushing NYC. i was in SF on vacation and my good friend had taken us out to this little spot. they just had many wonderful dishes. 

Mutton in cumin was fantastic, tender and spicy. Same with the beef and spicy fish stew. I would recommend all Szechuan food lovers to come try this place out if you haven't! I also love how they incorporated jalepenos into their cooking. very creative!

I was in SF for a total of 4 days and was here for dinner twice.
author: Brian L.

description: As a sichuanese person who goes to every sichuanese restaurants I can find, I could say this is the best place to go to in San Fran.
author: Monnikka M.

description: One of the best sichuan places I've tried in a while - things were spicy and hot. We ordered the intestines (yummm), eggplant, spicy fish dish (not the chef special), and cumin lamb. Yummyyy not overly salty and the right level of spiciness. Reasonable prices and a good amount of asians so you know it's authentic. Got in at around 6 and a line formed by the time we got out at around 730. The place is pretty small so they kind of rush you to get out once you're done.. but they do it in kind of a polite way so I can't stay mad. They take credit card but gave us discount for using cash.
author: Ruby C.

description: Excellent Sichuan food. Best ma po tofu I've had outsife of China. Other dishes were also excellent. One area for improvement would be the service. We had a bit of a wait to get someone's attention for water. Will be back.
author: Brian H.

description:
This is what you want.  I was brought here a year or two ago by friends and have been coming ever since.  Nothing else matters except the food.  
Chef's special fish stew - bomb.  
Sliced pork - bomb.  
Crispy deep fried taro and lotus root - bomb.  (If you combine the sliced pork and the taro and lotus root in one bite, you will think you died and went to food heaven.)  Dumplings in chili liquid - bomb.  
Soup dumplings - bomb. 
I can keep going, but I don't think I've ever had anything here that wasn't awesome.  Except the goopy warm tapioca dessert that they give you for free at the end, but I can overlook that.  
We usually come here with a decently sized group and order a bunch of food, so the waitress frequently gives us an order or two of soup dumplings on the house - bomb.  
The best thing besides the food? The price!!  You can eat until you can't eat anymore and have a few drinks, it'll run you about $15-20/person.
author: Mary V.

description:
Dan Dan Mian. 

A lot soupier than the SPICES II version, and not as flavorful. Plenty of heat but lacking the sichuan peppercorn presence. Big portion of noodles. Waitress was friendly and helpful with her limited vocab. $6.95. I'd come back for some different dishes.
author: Anthony R.

description:
Look, if I tell you that the food isn't great, will you leave my gem alone and keep it from becoming popular and going downhill? Because right now it is BOMB and the food is the right mix of make-me-sweat-spicy and numb-my-mouth-spicy and maybe the restaurant won't do that anymore if it gains the notoriety of Burma Superstar?

Ok, fine, I'll let you know that it's good. But don't tell anyone else! This will just be our little secret. If you go, order this:
- The house fish in chili special (UGNGH this makes my mouth burn so painfully in such a good way; the fish is always fresh and they give you a lot of it)
- Couples delight (is this what it's called in English? Shoot, I don't remember. Anyway, it's a offal appetizer and it's mixed in chili oil.)
- Chicken with chili (I have no idea what this is called in English. Umm, try saying laziji and see if that works? This is crispy pieces of chicken with peppers. So good, y'all.)
- Dry-fried string beans (because eating vegetables is important)

And rice or some other starch, to quench the heat in your mouth when you're suffering from that excruciating yet deeply-satisfying burn. UGNGHUGH this place makes me so happy and sweaty and excited. 

Please keep this on the DL, ok?
author: Annie M.

description:
Ordered:
Chefs Special Shrimp- Good
Shreaded Pork in Garlic Sauce-  OK but only the top part of the pork has enough seasoning... when you get to the bottom, the meat lacks sauce and tastes too pain
Steamed Chicken in Chili Sauce- A DISAPPOINTMENT

Overall, there are probably better szechuan places in the city...
author: Jen L.

description: Good service and good food! Recommended for delicious and authentic Sichuan food. Try the spicy beef in Chili oil with green beans and rice. You won't regret it.
author: V J.

description: I don't know what to say.  This place is fantastic.  I've only been twice but once was with a larger group and I was excited to try out ten dishes at once!  Every single one of them was delicious.  The staff was good and the main lady (manager/owner?) was funny and nice.  I would definitely return and hope to soon.
author: Johnny O.

description:
Update: Much better my last few visits. They do get frequent customers out the door faster on take out. Like the loyalty factor. Food is great and authentic and inexpensive.

Old Review: I frequented this restaurant weekly since it opened but am finding that the preparation of the food is declining. The descriptions of the food in English are difficult to translate for the common Sichuan dishes. Several times I have asked whether food is prepared a certain way to ensure that the dish I order is correct, have been assured and received something different. 

It's disappointing as they were off to a great start and with its popularity, declined from what they started with.

I will still eat here but less frequently.
author: Debbie C.

description:
We came here because his dad raved about it sooooo much that we had to try it.

We ordered the couples delight (beef tendons and tripe), cuttlefish, homemade home-cut noodles [SOOOOOO GOOD]  and fried pork stuffed eggplant [AGAIN SOOOOO GOOD]. Overall delicious! Except everything was drenched in layers of oil and there was so much batter on the eggplants. Still good only cuz i love eggplants!

Another great thing, HUGE PORTIONS!!!! Leftovers for sure.

Its a good szechuan place, definitely coming back!
author: Anna H.

description:
I went last night and was disappointed with the meal. 

We had the cold chicken dish to start, which was essentially chopped chicken on the bone in chili oil, garnished with cucumbers and cilantro. I've seen this dish served with shredded chicken which is a better prep to absorb the oil and spices, but maybe that was Hunan style. This dish was very difficult to eat, as the slices were too thin, and not much heat to the dish.

The wontons in chili oil were fine, a decent version.

#30, Sichuan fish?, was deep fried tilapia I believe, again on the bone. This was also very difficult to eat, getting fish bones in almost every bite. It was garnished with fried rice crakers, jalapenos, and dried chilies. The fish was muddy tasting, and needed more seasoning.

I liked the complimentary plate of seaweed and pickled cabbage.

Go to Spices! or Z&Y instead.
author: Derrick V.

description: Got the chefs special fish, green beans and 口水鸡, yum! Great service, everyone was really friendly, tea was good....will definitely be back for more. This is bookmarked as one of my favorite Sichuan restaurants in SF
author: Gloria M.

description: Solid Sichuan restaurant. Really quick, thorough, and friendly service. Although everything we ordered was good, don't do what we did and order a bony duck and a bony chicken at the same time; it gets rather boring. Rather, go for variety. I'd come back here again.
author: Keito U.

description:
hot and sour noodle was average
frog leg pot (frog was subpar, veggie was ok) slightly better than last time
beer duck was subpar
la meat was good (too salty
author: Diane W.

description: One of the Best Chinese restaurant in SF! Love the chef's special fish stew.  Everything is tasty. Volume is huge too. Waitress are all nice.
author: Seddie S.

description: After a few disappointed trips to other Sichuan restaurants, eg. Z&Y and Grand hot pot lounge,  we decided to give Sichuan Home a try, and were pleased that we did. The restaurant is small, not much decorations, but the food was great. We ordered chef's specialty boiled fish, a pork dish, and a tofu dish. Our order came out in 10 minutes, and they were hot, delicious and savory, and very authentic. My husband said it's the best Sichuan restaurant in San Francisco. We can't wait to go back to try more of their dishes.
author: Millie T.

description: An authentic Chinese restaurant with friendly staff, decent prices, tasty food, and a nice/clean atmosphere. The menus and decor are exactly like they would be in a nicer restaurant in Sichuan. The food is authentic and the service was very good. Complimentary tea, small appetizer, and small dessert. We spoke (or attempted to speak) Chinese with the waitresses and they really got a kick out of it. Will return!
author: Luke K.

description: The wonton soup with chili oil was amazing. I tried the beef with cut noodles and was turned off when I noticed intestines in it. But the food was otherwise all very very good, great service, clean, and nice people. The crunch veggie salad was great too. I would go again for sure.
author: Justin B.

description: I love everything that I ordered from here so far! Will definitely return for more yummy dishes
author: Marilyn O.

description:
Holy god. The food was excellent! The staff was attentive and friendly, and it was a great deal. I got the frog legs in chili oil (which wasn't super oily/greasy), $13 pretax for a large portion.  Whenever I eat out I usually order 2 entrees because I exercise and eat a lot, but this time I only got one (plus rice and the free veg side of spicy cabbage and seaweed salad (and not the overly sweet, artificial weird radioactive green dyed kind)) and I left full.  I personally prefer some of the legs to be cooked a little less, but I suppose it's hard to control that since it comes in a stew.  I was pleasantly surprised to find that although the dish has "oil" in the title, it was more like a (spicy) stew, which I would sip with a bite of rice.  But! They just kinda cut the whole frog up, bones and all, so pay attention to what you are eating!  Gonna have to use your fingers and pick out little fragments.

Wasn't really feelin' the rice porridge dessert at the end, but at that point I was already satisfied, plus the oranges were fresh and juicy.  

I will be back!
author: Josh J.

description: Seriously delicious and hot food! Came here for a friend's birthday dinner with a party of 8 and we ate up a storm that formed many beads of sweat on at least a few foreheads. I didn't order so I cannot say what all the dishes are properly called, but pretty much everything we got here was good. Dan Dan noodles, spicy fish (cooked in a pool of chili oil soup at the table), pan fried buns, shredded pork in garlic sauce and onion pancake all made it to the table and then our stomachs, and those are just the dishes whose names I can recall. Definitely looking forward to coming here again!
author: Allie Y.

description:
If you're looking for a light, easy meal of dumplings and fried rice, you might as well stop reading here and never come to Sichuan Home. If you crave spice (and not just heat!), proper doneness in cooking, and well balanced flavors, then you should definitely come here.

Despite my heritage, I am a huge fan of Sichuan food and for years now, Spices has been my go-to place. It wasn't always pretty, but at least the food was prompt and satisfying. But knowing that Sichuan Home is here means that I can never go back. My life is now divided into the period before I ate here and after. It's not a particularly impressive store front; decorations seemingly taken from a kitschy Italian trattoria and a clean, sparse interior belie the great service and spectacular food.

Even if the service weren't prompt and helpful, even if the fresh squeezed juices weren't ridiculously delicious, even if their prices weren't extremely reasonable, I would still have to come back here. We started with the Couple's Delight, a mish-mash of tendons, tripe, stomach, and other cuts of meat tossed in oil and spices. Without a doubt, this is the best single rendition of the dish I've had. Good Sichuan-style food is as much about the flowery notes as it is about the intense heat and the flavor was spot on; a little bit of heat from the peppers, a little fragrant aroma from the oils, and a nice dose of crunch from some peanuts.

Our red-oil wontons were really well done and miles better than the vinegar-doused version that Spices offers. Our main dishes included cumin spiced lamb (cooked with just enough pepper and onion for a slightly sweet and intriguingly savory flavor), the hot pot of fish (laden with vermicelli, bean sprouts, fungus, and rice cakes), and the chef's special chicken, which was skewered chicken lightly fried and then cooked in a fiery broth, also filled with bean sprouts and fungus.

The service was impeccable with nary a single empty tea cup and a gracious serving of freshly-made pumpkin cakes filled with red bean. As we packed up our few lonely leftovers, one of the waitresses came by to insist that we take some of the broth so that we could cook some fresh vegetables in it later.

I've now spent all the energy I had writing this review and must retire to bed so that I can dream about when I'll be able to get my next hurts-so-good fix.
author: Marcus L.

description: I love Sichuan food and this was nice for a fix. Sadly though the food looked much better than it tasted and considering the competition in SF I have to say 3 stars. I had the Ma Po Tofu, Kung Pao Chicken, braised vege with fungus, and some Shanghai dumplings. the latter two were good. The first two just lacked flavor, they need to kick up the ginger in the kung pao and something about the ma po just wasn't quite there for me.
author: Christopher Steven O.

description:
YUM!

My parents favorite place to get beef noodle soup.  Why?  Because they  make some delicious and interesting dao chow noodles.  Mmm...

It's like tagliatelle cut and made by hand, but much wider and more awesome mixed with beef noodle deliciousness!  Love this stuff!  Definitely worth a try.

Spices-wise, I would just go for hot.  They kindly brought out my medium spicy beef noodles, which looked too normal.  I asked them to add some heat and got a bowl of red hot goodness.  Just enough spice!

Total mom-and-pop shop, but clean.  Small place that reminded me and the hubby of an old school Italian joint?  I'm not sure what it is, but all it's missing is those red-and-white checkered table cloths.

Overall, loved the flavor of our food and great service.  Hard to park, but if I found a space nearby I would definitely wander over to this place!
author: Christine K.

description: terrific food, hella friendly server. we had vegetable dumplings, wonton in spicy sauce and onion pancakes. the wontons were SO GOOD. must order. vegetable dumplings were really good, too. you could tell they had just been made. yum.
author: Dana D.

description:
I'm a Pavlov's dog for Sichuan Home. Went last night for the first time and my mouth is still watering for the delicious pan-fired beef short ribs. Actually, I'm eating the leftovers for lunch right now because of the generous portions. 

You have to stop everything while eating this food to get the full depth of flavor in every bite.

I'll be back.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Came here randomly because nearby restaurant was over a hour wait and we had a friend who needed to head to the airport. 

We ordered:
XO Sauce with beef & tripe
Wonton w/chili oil
House special chicken
Dou Miao vegetable
Spicy Beef Dish (not sure on the name)
Cuttlefish

Everything was really good! I especially enjoyed the cuttlefish dish, it wasn't overly salty or spicy and they were cooked perfectly. My friend liked the house special chicken the most... chicken was tender, even tho a bit bland, but that's only because everything else was packed with tons of flavor. We finished everything!

Waitresses had nice friendly attitude, but service was just ok because you have to constantly call them over to remind them to bring tea, utensils, or to bring our rice even though our food came. Plus side, the food comes out pretty fast and hot!

Will go back again!
author: Wei-Wei C.

description: The food is quite authentic from my point of view. The flavor of the spicy cold plate chicken was on spot. It is seasoned very well but in the mean time not too oily. The spicy fish was cooked right in front of you on a gas stove. The portion of the spicy fish was huge!  If you are a fan of Szechwan food, don't miss it!
author: Hua W.

description:
Food taste 4 stars
Service 3 stars
Check your bill to avoid overcharge.
author: Panda H.

description:
I thought the food was pretty good

My friend and I ordered everything Spicy of course

and we did the premade mixed pot full of vegetables, dumplings and rice noodles!

it was great!!!!! they gave us so much food and it was full of spiciness to it!
i am not a big fan of chinese food, but for this is was still pretty good.
author: Sophia W.

description:
Finally!! Real sichuan food! :) Who would have thought it'd be next to impossible to find authenticity in a city with tons of Chinese people and Chinese restaurants and a Chinatown run by actual Chinese? But the food--mapo tofu and spicy veg was oh so worth it.

The restaurant is relatively small -- maybe two large tables and five medium tables and the medium tables fill up quickly during dinnertime. On Friday evenings, it's best to arrive around 5pm because the tables fill quickly and there have been lines. If you happen to go during a busy time and there's only one or two in your party, the waitress may ask to fill the empty seats at your table with some folks standing in line. Those of you who like the idea of stranger dinners will embrace that request, but for those of you who are annoyed, takeout might be your solution. 

The food is delicious, spicy, and yummy. You can even special request dishes that are not on the menu.
author: Melissa K.

description:
I ordered 

pumpkin bread with red bean paste, it's really good.

sweet and sour pork rib. it's good but a bit fatty.

service is pretty good, better than average chinese restaurant.

I like their menu , lots of variety.
author: Rina C.

description: The first time I ate here I loved it. The second time I went, I had already fallen out of love. The food just wasn't as fresh and vibrant as it had been on my first visit 6 months earlier. I enjoyed the Chinese bacon dish we ordered along with the twice cooked pork, but I felt like the fire was a little lacking in the other dishes we ordered. The service was warm and welcoming at first but the waitress tried to pull a shady trick at the end, telling me they were not accepting credit cards as it was a holiday and instructing me to pay cash. I kept my cool and very firmly explained that we did not have sufficient cash and it's a violation of the merchant agreement to refuse Mastercard if you advertise on the door that you take it. Suddenly the waitress' attitude changed - she became very apologetic and ran my card. Petty and foolish.
author: Keith R.

description:
My girlfriend and I actually wanted to go to a nearby sushi place, but it was closed in the interim between lunch and dinner.  So we opted for Sichuan Home.  Totally glad we did!  This place is great.  

We ordered noodle soup with beef (not spicy), noodle soup with pork (medium spicy), and pork dumplings.  The beef soup had HUGE chunks of tender beef in it.  I'm used to pho or pho-style soup having slices of beef, so this was a nice surprise.  It also had bamboo chutes and leeks in it.  The broth was light, but overall the soup was very filling.

My soup actually had very little pork in it, which was a little disappointing, but the broth and other stuff was great.  The noodles were thick, hand-cut szechuan-style noodles, and the soup also had kale and edamame in it.  The broth was flavorful and at the perfect level of spice (for me).  

The pork dumplings were delicious, and the sesame oil they served with it was the bomb.  

All in all, a pretty good place.  The service isn't that great, so if you need something you'll have to ask repeatedly for it.  I get the impression that's what people expect from authentic asian places like this, though, so take that how you will.
author: Jace P.

description:
We stumbled upon this unassuming restaurant last Thursday and were extremely happy with that decision. The restaurant was full with tables of mostly young Asian twenty-somethings. The moment we walked in, the entire restaurant went silent and stared at us (clue #1 we are in a good place). The server quickly cleaned off a table and sat us near the door. At first glance of the menu, we realized we had actually found an authentic Sichuan restaurant. A moment of euphoria took over as I remembered the mouthwatering dishes of Sichuan province that I sampled a few years back. I had been looking for spicy chicken just like the little hole-in-the wall restaurant in Chengdu and I finally had found it. I also had my brother with me who has been living in China for the past seven years and fancies himself somewhat of a Sichuan expert. 

Between the three of us, we ordered MaPo DouFu, Spicy Chicken (bone-in), Beef with Vegetables, potstickers, and egg rolls. I was blown away with the authenticity of the MaPo DouFu and the Spicy Chicken. My mouth was numb with the familiar burn of Sichuan chili oil and I loved it. The only disappointing dish was the beef with vegetables. My husband ordered it because he is a Mongolian Beef kind of guy and loves American-Chinese food. The vegetables were horribly disappointing as they were the frozen pea and carrot mix that once graced cafeterias across the United States. 

The bill was $40 for three people for all the food we ordered. You should definitely head to this little restaurant in the Outer Richmond. You will not be disappointed with its authentic flavors; however, your mouth will be on fire from the chili oil. Yum!
author: Alice S.

description:
Tried the Sichuan Home restaurant on Christmas day.  There was a packed house and lots of different folks enjoying nice hot meals.  We ordered the Won Ton in Hot Chili.  The best that I have had: nice soft and delicious won ton in chili sauce and pea sprouts. We also had chicken corn soup - good.  We ordered the Chef Special vegetables - not to our liking as we did not know what was in there.  The Kung pao chicken was good and spicy.  Lastly, the crispy noodles was good too. 

Service was good even for a busy evening.
author: J Z.

description: Authentic or not the food was HORRIBLE but somehow the service was even worse. First of all the menu is huge and nothing has detailed descriptions so you are pretty much just guessing. The butterfly shrimp was whole (with eyes) and pretty tasteless. The chicken with ginger sauce was bite sized pieces with tons of BONES/BONE SHARDS in every bite. Really not good and hard to eat. The server did not check in with us once to see if we were enjoying our meal, probably because she was on the phone the entire time. The restaurant was empty and there was no music so it was very noticeable. We left hungry and unsatisfied.
author: Deja B.

description:
I'm in love! This is the best Szechuan food I've tried outside of Shanghai, China to date. I've been looking SO long for a place to live up to real Szechuan standards, and this place is the best you can get (at least out of what I've tried so far!) My stomach is so happy. I have been searching for far too long, and now I have finally found my long lost lover. The service is incredible and friendly, the food is flavorful and addiction-inducing, and I'm pretty sure that going here just made my day. 

Even the free cabbage with carrots and hot Szechuan sauce they give you in the beginning of the meal makes me salivate. OMG. I'm a hair's length from sneaking over the fridge in the middle of the night just to get another taste of that spicy goodness...
author: Michelle G.

description: While still good, not as enthused by this place anymore, its staid and not progressive with the menu remaining the same and a lame health score.  I'll still eat here and still go through the restaurant kitchen, to go to the bathroom, however apparently not on their game as much.  After more thought, its just not as good as Z and Y, which is super consistently delicious.  However here you cannot go wrong with the spicy wonton, their Chef Special veggies, oxymoronically delicous as well.  I like the black pepper beef, but they used to use tenderloin, now its just eye of round or similar, still tender but not silky tender, this coming from an eschewer of tenderloin.  Still Recommend 1/2+
author: Kevin M.

description: Authentic taste, although not quite as numbingly spicy as the real thing. Courteous and attentive staff make the experience all the better. Don't leave without getting one of the spicy fish dishes!
author: Daniel L.

description: The flavors! Delicious food that is ready fast. However is definitely better to come here with a group than solo. I asked for a sweet and sour soup small portion and was denied,  saying it only comes in bigger portions. I asked for fried rice but said I could only get white with my individual meal.
author: Bonnie N.

description:
While attempting to determine the veracity of a friends raves regarding Lou's Cafe I discovered those losers close at 7. With an empty stomach I despondently stumbled into the Chinese restaurant next door.

Just my luck that it was one of the top 10 picks of the Examiner last year.

I got the ( Examiner recomended ) vegitarian combo. Holy cow balls, it was good. Pine nuts, taro, bits of green something or another. It more than sated my hunger and made the friend I visited jealous with hunger as well. What a winning combination!!

Bonus: I show up there, a simple white boy wearing a hoody from a rap band. Waitress offers me a choice: Fork or Chopsticks. I choose Fork. She shakes her head and tells me "I think you'll do better with chopsticks." HOW DID SHE KNOW MY HIDDEN TALENT?!?!
author: Ethan R.

description: the service has gotten alot better. they are very nice and caring to their customers and tries to accommodate. but given not alot of staff, small place, there is a bit of wait. but food is good and pretty authentic and cost is not too bad. def good to try.
author: Food Is L.

description: Everything was flavorful and well cooked. There are a lot of exotic dishes and fantastic choices! My new favorite place!
author: Kory-Oren E.

description: Nice. Spicy. No idea what some things were but yum.
author: Russell S.

description: I went there last night ordered pan fried shrimp&lamb and Dan Dan noodle. They were pretty plain, tasteless and I was pretty upset coz I came for their good review on yelp. Surprisingly, their customer services worth 4stars as they brought the dish back to the kitchen again to make it spicy and served us complimentary green bean soup. I would go there one more time to give them another chance try something different just for their services.
author: Jeannie Y.

description:
I hate tasting food cooked in starch and soy sauce, it's like eating someone else's saliva, eww!  

However, Sichuan Home is worth a try if you like to eat authentic but not too spicy Sichuan food. All the dishes we ordered are quite delicious and light. Even my 2 years old son likes their Dandan noodle. 

The service is awesome too, which is rare among Chinese restaurants.
author: Wen H.

description:
By far the most authentic and tasty food if you know and understand what to expect.  Do your home work, don't whine about oil or spice.  Eat like king or queen!  Caution it will intimidate you!

Sauted Beef in Red Chili is magnificent and a large portion.  Bring friends especially ones that aren't sissy about the heat!
author: Kashif M.

description: good price good severies,tasty and spicy,after meal they will give us dissert for free,anyways I will come back.
author: Kelly X.

description:
- surprisingly empty at 6p (just one other table)
- garlic cucumber: some of the best ive had. Fresh and crisp cucumbers with lots of garlic and they added ma la
- fuji feipian: on par w some of the best I've had. A good balance of meats, cartilage and innards.
- suan la fen: the brother was good but the noodles were a little overcooked
author: Charlito B.

description:
Decided to try it yet again.  Food was decent, but not great.  Fish filet in chili oil had spice but not a lot of flavor.  Still no sign of any sichuan peppers or the Ma La flavor that another reviewer claimed to have tasted in abundance. Whole garlic in the sauce was hard and uncooked, an indicator that it hadn't been cooking very long (and certainly not long enough).  

Three times now and the same reaction every time - severely lacking in the flavor that's the hallmark of Sichuan cuisine.

I still can't find anywhere better than Dong Bei mama for Sichuan food in SF.
author: Ritch G.

description:
Definitely a fan of this place. My friends and I went based on the Yelp reviews and honestly pretty blindly. We've gone to legit Szechwan restaurants before and are always expecting a certain "style" of restaurant and food. I will say that our experience here was a bit confusing... but delicious nonetheless.

First off... why does every Szechwan restaurant I know have home, garden, house, place, or palace after a variation of the word Szechwan? Just a random thought... On to the food! Do you like spicy? Check! Do you like not too heavy, oily, greasy? Check! Do you LOVE Xiaolongbao or soup dumplings? MMMMM CHECK!  It's a weird menu of a whole bunch of "chinese" stuff thrown together. Honestly our group was expecting one thing (when we ordered) and all looked at each other when the food came out b/c it's not exactly what we thought it was going to be. But it was legit, good and delicious.
author: Jamie P.

description: We come to SF about every two months to visit my mom.  We found this place after seeing the long line for Lou's sandwich shop.  We were a little nervous at first but wow it was absolutely amazing!!!  Our favorites are the chow mein (3 different meats), sweet and sour pork, pot stickers, and egg rolls.  They bring out each item as it is ready and hot.  Great service, excellent food, and very good prices.  Best Chinese food we found in the city.
author: Cindy G.

description:
Holy Sichuan, Batman. This place rocks. I went here with my sister the last time we visited, and we gorged on the fried pork belly (in oil & pepeprs?), greens (snow pea leaves?) with garlic, and clay pot...and something else. As lifelong Chinese food eaters, with my sister having been to Chengdu, we both agreed it was da*n delicious. 

Do yourself a favor, and get thee some fried pork belly. Also, don't forget to add something green to counter its fiery fatty effects.
author: Kid F.

description: I'm from Sichuan and this is the most authentic Sichuan food I've had in bay area so far and the price is very good as well. Enough said.
author: Will W.

description: I also like the other spicy restaurants over this one. The servers/waitresses/owner here really try to sweet talk you into ordering more and the pricy dishes. The spicy soaked fish I ordered last time was also not well cooked like the other reviewers mentioned.  It's basically not cooked through, and you simply can't chew through it.  It's got on my "not to go/not preferred" list now.. Disappointed.  Oh, by the way, true that they also didn't serve us water at all until we asked... poor quality of service in place unfortunately.
author: Michelle K.

description: We went there yesterday for dinner again. Every dish tasted authentic and definitely fresh! Waitress has always passion and great service! My family all love this  Sichuan restaurant! One star off because one dish which contains lamb and shrimp was a bit on salt side. If you're a Chinese or you're a big fan of spicy foods, highly recommend!
author: Ting L.

description: its ok after we visited for second time. found out the food made us feel very thirsty so not a good sign -- that means they use a lot of monosodium glutamate， something that makes food flavorful yet does no good to your body.
author: Shuting Z.

description: Food is good but service is not that good. Waitress seemed want us to leave quickly, we finish our dinner quick and leave because there are lot of people waiting here.
author: Vic D.

description: Came here at a 10:10 on a Sunday. They decided to close early.   Was hoping that this would be a late night spot I can go to on weekends. FAIL! Could not understand a thing they were saying. PLEASE change ur advertised hours!
author: Demanding T.

description: Gave this place a second try, and trust me, there are at least 2-4 key ingredients absent in each dish.  It's like the chef from R&G came up with an idea to open a Sichuan restaurant.  Just not happening.  I don't expect your average San Franciscan or Cantonese patron to understand Sichuan food, but this ain't it.  We had to take the leftovers home and to "Frankenstein" it up.  It's sad because a bunch of you who eat here will find it delicious and the day you are actually presented with Sichuan cuisine you will think there is something wrong....  Otherwise, this place is fine...
author: Laurence H.

description: Authentic spicy Chinese food!  Food here is very good and the price is reasonable!  This place gets packed around 6p-8p on the weekends so it's a good idea to call ahead.  Parking here is bad.   =(
author: K L.

description:
My favorite Sichuan restaurant in the city.  I came here when they just opened and immediately fell in love with this restaurant.  Almost everything we've ordered so far are delicious. My favorite is their spicy wonton, and my bf's favorite is the cumin lamb.  I since then took my friends here, and all of them loved it here and kept coming back.  

The waitresses are super nice and friendly.  They'll even watch your car if you park at the meter in front of the restaurant. I do admit, you'll probably know what to order.  For the record, I'm Chinese and actually grew up in China.  As far as I can remember, my family never orders kungpao chicken at restaurants...
author: Eva S.

description: A place that specializes in Chengdu style Sichuan cuisine -- meaning they can crank up the spice if you ask them to, but you do have to ask, as they're probably more used to customers expecting generic style Chinese food. Go for the regional specialties on the menu -- the saliva chicken (I know it sounds gross, but that is the literal translation of the Chinese name of the dish "koushuiji" -- anyway, it's good). They also do a Chengdu version of the Dandan Mian.
author: Chris L.

description: We usually come here if we want to eat spicy food. Today I tried the one on clement st (chili house), And it gives me a motivation to come here and write a review. This is honestly the best Sichuan food in the Bay Area!( I tried more than 15 Sichuan restaurants and I a spicy food lover)
author: Johnny Y.

description: I always like to try new kind of food around the city. This was the right place to make the that happen. Never tried frogs in my life and on that day it happened. Never tried dumplings and guess what on that day I was truly impressed, Check , it happened. Most of the food is spicy so if you are a person that cannot tolerate spiciness , honestly not only that your missing out on this kind of chines food but you cant get away with anything in the menu. Overall experience is great the service, food, and environment are great.
author: Sulaiman B.

description:
A friend asked David Chang for a Chinese restaurant recommendation in San Francisco and Chang said "Mission Chinese." Another friend asked the chef at Mission Chinese what HIS favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco is and he said "Sichuan Home." 

There you have it, folks: the restaurant David Chang would recommend if he knew better.

It's small and the staff was efficient and patient with our not-speaking-Chinese ways. Hot and sour rice noodles, fried calamari, spicy beef short ribs, special vegetable combo, cabbage with pepper oil - my only regret was not bringing enough people along to try more dishes.
author: Will R.

description: I have probably ordered the wrong thing.  For appetizer, I had tea smoked duck.  It was not what I expected.  I thought it would something like Peking duck.  It wasn't.  Something salty and cold which tasted like leftover food that you just grabbed out of refrigerator without heating it up.  However, maybe it is supposed to be like that.  For main course, I asked for a recommendation on the fish.  What I got was a big bowl of white fish with cabbage, dried chili, garlic completely drenched in diluted solution of chili oil.  Pretty much a soup of chili oil.  One piece of this would be ok.  The fish was actually good.  However, as a main course I don't think so.  After several bites, all you feel is chili oil.  And the weird thing is that is was not that spicy.  Well, again, maybe those are typical Szechuan dishes.  Not ordering rice was also a mistake.  It might have absorbed some of the oil.  Do your research when you come.
author: Pasha G.

description: The BEST Sichuan food in San Francisco! Better than Z&Y in China town. It's also cheaper.
author: Jessie C.

description: The beef with broccoli was incredible! I will be more adventurous next time.  Wonderful pot stickers with a proper sauce - not just soy with a few floating scallions like so many places (outside of SF, that is).
author: Roger H.

description:
Wow, I was so disappointed in this place.  I really like trying different Sichuan places all over, so I had certain expectations about the cuisine.  This place had a very boring beef noodle soup, with thin weak broth and tough beef.  The worst was the spicy fried fish.  At most places the batter used is a magic mix of spicy and peppery sensations.  Here it was bland and the fish was dry and full of bones - to the point that it was just too difficult to eat.

Is the food authentic?  I can't say.  But if it is, I imagine it being authentic food from a Chinese prison, village hospital, or Dickensian orphanage.

Go to SPICES! or TASTE of FORMOSA instead.
author: Adam T.

description: Looking for authentic, spicy food from the Chinese Sichuan province?  This is the real deal.  I've been coming here every Friday night for years now, I'm beyond hooked!
author: David N.

description:
What a DISAPPOINTMENT!  We came here after reading an article about this place calling it the "best new Asian restaurant" and seeing the promising reviews here. We are big fans of Szechuan flavor, but this was common at best.

The menu does not look impressive and the prices are high for this type of restaurant. Plates, even small ones, start at $11.

As soon as we ordered we got a small plate of pickled cabbage, celery, and carrots - nice gesture. By the way, the chopsticks here are made from hard plastic, which makes it hard to eat anything greasy (like everything here).

The small plate of Garlic Cucumbers was just cut cucumbers with garlic and floating in a sea of low quality chili oil.

The Chef's Special Fish Stew ($18.95!!!) was served in a baking dish with a spoon that kept sinking inside. We were never brought bowls or individual spoons or offered rice. The stew itself was covered with a thick layer of grease, the fish in it was slimy and flavorless, and the chili peppers were low quality. After few bites we asked for the check.

Overall it was a very underwhelming experience. It made us appreciate "Spices" on 8th and Clement Ave so much more. "Spices" is the place to go for authentic Szechuan food, not here.
author: LJ I.

description:
Great salad with jicama and long thin roots

i like the little bowl of stuff they put out before the meal.

homey spot that feels good and good service
author: Ron A.

description: Wow. They made us wait, seated a north East Asian couple who came in 5min after us, that couple got their food and water refilled before we even got any water. It was beyond clear that they did NOT want to serve us. As an Asian myself, I felt very discriminated.
author: Melody P.

description:
first, i did not wight review very often, because most time even i just feels a little "ok" with any service i did not want to write anything, second, whatever how bad the food how bad the service, i still will tip my server, because i know i must do that, because they are not boss, they need money to make a life.
but this time, i must write the review to let any people what happened. i traveled to San Francisco, that day is the last day i stayed there, i check online, found this place. when i went in, the lady(boss) was very warm, she suggested several food, someone we ordered, she said that is small size, you need order bigger one, you need also order some extra vege, i said that is ok, we just follow what she said, i really don't care the extra charge. Be honest, the food is ok, not bad, but later, we i asked the "bill",  the crazy thing happened. she gave me the price list from the calculator, not fish $10, beef $10, it is $10, $20$30....., between them there was $8, i didn't know what was that, i think maybe we spent $40, not $50 something, in the beginning i want to tip another $10, suddenly i thought i needed ask what was that, she said it was tip, i asked her, we only think over 6 people you can charge 15% by yourself, not only two people, you also need give me the detail, not only the price, she said sorry, i can take it away, or you can pay cash, give you some discount, i say "no", i still tipped you the $8, but i won't be back
if i did not ask, i would tip her (the boss) $18, do not go there, be careful the price, they are not honest!!!!!!!!! super!!!!!!!!
author: Tom L.

description:
We went here tonight since it's really close to our place, and to be honest, was one of the few places open after 10 pm.

The food tasted really good at first, and really spicy.  But frankly, the more we ate and the closer we got to the bottom, it just tasted like plain oil.  And at the bottom of our containers was a big puddle of grease.

The food was just too greasy for me to keep eating.  Maybe we ordered the wrong thing.  Maybe it was just late and they just threw it together, but I don't think I can go there again.

Oh and both the beef and chicken were really rubbery and chewy.
author: Ana R.

description: I wouldn't call this place a hole in the wall, but it's very small and straightforward - no bells and whistles here. It was pretty full when we went, and it was definitely an off-peak hour (between 3-4pm). I would say this place serves up your typical Sichuan cuisine - lots and lots of oil, and lots and lots of red chili peppers. We had to ask for some of our dishes to be simply steamed with no oil, as this kind of food can quickly become overwhelming. We ordered the Chef's special fish and tofu in spicy sauce and it was delicious. There was SO much tender fish in the dish that we couldn't even finish it. I honestly can't remember the other dishes we tried but in the end, we did feel overwhelmed by all the chili oil. Nonethless, this is Sichuan cuisine done right, and I can see why it's a neighborhood favorite!
author: Stella Y.

description: This place is excellent.  The service was very good when we went.  The staff was cheerful and our food came out fast.  We ordered the beef knife noodles, pea shoots and the Sichuan spicy chicken.  Next time I want to try the spicy fish and the chef's veggie combo.  The menu is huge, there is so much to try I will need to come back once a week.
author: Sarah R.

description:
still eating my way through the menu:

yey:
-beef noodle soup (lots of curry and cumin, great winter soup)
-kung pao chicken was a nice spicy variation from the norm and loaded with peanuts.

meh:
-xlb soup dumplings were overcooked and not soupy enough
author: Josie M.

description: Of course this place opens up right around the corner from my apartment right after I move up to Marin.  Sichuan Home really makes me miss the city.  I'd give this place 5 stars but I don't want it to become another b-superstar.
author: Josh G.

description: Excellent food. Red chili oil wontons!
author: Bowen D.

description: We came at 4:30pm and no other customers were there. We ordered the chef special spicy fish stew and the owner tried to push their more expensive fish dish on us. That should have been my 1st clue! We also ordered some steamed Bao-tse to counter the spicyness of the fish, plus 2 glasses of water. The bao-tse didn't come to our table until over 35 minutes and by then, we were already done with the fish! I had asked twice about the bao-tse and both times was told it takes 15 minutes to prepare! I explained why we no longer wanted it, but the owner insisted we take them! The fish was good, but the service was horrible! Btw, the water was never served! Will not come back again!
author: tom c.

description: I went to this restaurant on a Saturday night and it was packed! Fortunately, I made reservations because I was celebrating my graduation with my family. Their food and service is A+++...no joke. However, their portion sizes are small. There are too many great dishes to recommend so I won't list it all. I loved the Vegetable Combo and the Pumpkin Sesame Rice Cake the most! I only took half a piece of the rice cake and the next thing I know, they were all gone! In fact, my sibling asked me for half of my half rice cake! This is definitely a great place to eat with family or friends!
author: Pedro M.

description: Quick, cheap, and generous: No complaints. The hot pot veggies, cumin lamb, and cold fun were all great.
author: Sam B.

description: Worst customer service ever and wouldn't recommand anyone come here. If you are expecting some decent customer service then this is definitely not the place for you.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
My first yelp review, even though I have been a loyal user for years.

I just had to let people know about this awesome new restaurant, in the hopes that they get enough business to stay around, because I don't think I will be able to survive without it!

I am from northern China and miss Northern food.  Don't get me wrong, I like Cantonese food just fine, but it is nice to have other flavors of Chinese food available.  

The dish names are kind of weird, because they are translated directly from Chinese, but this place is definitely authentic and has a huge menu, so ask the waitresses for suggestions.

What I have tried and loved so far: Szechuan Tea Duck, Couple's Delight (beef slices in spicy oil), Boiled Fish Fillet in Spicy Sauce, Salty Bamboo w/ Soy Beans & Winter Melon, Ginger Sauce Chicken Pot.

Don't let the hot pepper signs on the menu deter you, even my Cantonese in-laws said the food was not that spicy.
author: Anon A.

description: Been to Sichuan home many times. Food and service were always good. Our favourite restaurant for spicy food in SF.
author: Da D.

description: Overall, food was really good.  We had the wonton in chili oil to start, then the beef noodle soup and kung pao chicken.  I gave it 4 stars instead of 5 because I thought it was a little pricey for what it is and there were way too much star anise and other inedible seeds in the beef noodle soup.
author: Lily L.

description: Looking for real Sichuan style food? then this is it. 4 kung fu stars solid all around. I'll be baaaack.
author: Geronimo K.

description:
This place is very clean and their food is so good.
Their chili fish is just like the one I ate in China. 

SF is sooo cold right now. You definitely need some HOT food.
author: Jenny Y.

description: Good sichuan cuisine!I love the fish and shrimp. Thses are very fresh. The dishes are not sweet and not spicy too much. The restraurant uses good chili. And I also like the  Benben Chicken and Deep-Fried Pumpkin Cake! Although it still have sth different from sichuan cuisine in china, but I think that it is good enough. The restanurant is not very big. There are 7 or 8 tables.But it is enough! There are always very hot!
author: Coral Z.

description: The food here isn't very good. It's very oily and too many dishes have an overpowering ingredient of peppercorn. A little peppercorn is okay, but they just overdo it. I haven't been to many Sichuan places, but I don't think I'd be interested in coming back to this place..
author: Yuan T.

description: Sichuan Home is one of those places you can suggest to a friend and be 100% sure that they will love it! Each dish is absolutely delightful and unique from other restaurants. Yes, the place can be spicy, but the hotness of the food is always complimentary and never hogs the center stage. If you are a light-weight like me, the friendly and courteous staff can always assist you in navigating the menu to develop a meal tailored to your flavor preference. My only worry about giving this restaurant 5 stars is that I do not want for it to get so popular that I won't be able to get a seat.
author: Chuck S.

description:
I was craving cheap Szechuan food and this place hit the spot! There were only two ladies bussing the entire restaurant.  They were incredibly busy for a Monday night, yet still very friendly when we did interact. Quite a rarity in small asian restaurants like this one.

We ordered sole (boneless fish filet option) in a basket, beef in chili oil, house noodles, and cumin lamb.  All were so damn tasty and spicy perfection!  

There was a delay in giving us our check when we were done. This didn't bother me and S.Heart, since all we could do was sit there and be full as hell. She gave us two fried red bean cakes as an apology. How nice! We will be coming back when the craving creeps up on us again.
author: T L.

description: Ordered the Spicy Chicken and it was great!!  Wasnt too crazy spicy and it was pretty huge portions for 12 bucks.  I will be back to check out their lunch specials.
author: Hugh L.

description: Found the voucher that was mentioned in a previous review and thought we'd check out this new place for the first time today. It was the perfect time for some nice hot chilli spicy boiled beef and chicken since the recent weather is so freaking cold. The wontons weren't too bad either, nicely wrapped and juicy. Service could have been a little quicker, but who cares, the food was great. Our check came out to $43 plus change, no problem at all using the voucher for $20 off. Would come again on any cold day!
author: Lisa L.

description: Very friendly service. We came to get carry out so I am reserving 5 stars for when I eat there. The food is spicy, if you want it. They also have the Sichuan pepper corn which adds that extra special flavor to food, and which my husband loves. The restaurant was pretty crowded during lunch time and I can't wait to go back to dine in.
author: Natalie S.

description: If any restaurant serves you a dish of frozen dumplings from a package, you know they should not be in business.  We had 6 reheated frozen huo tie (steamed dumplings) that tasted so bad and looked like more than a year old.  We paid $4.99 but did not have the nerve to eat them.  I could have brought 24 of them from a Chinese super market for $4.00!  When are they going be out of business?
author: Rich W.

description: Wife and I just moved to this area and randomly found this place.  What a great find!  We had a great meal and will definitely be back.  The string beans are so good, they are addictive!
author: Steve L.

description: The food is pretty good! Especially the fish called xiangshui fish. I think this dish is authentic. Very spicy, I like spicy food. And the dishes are service quickly. The environment is good, and the restaurant is not far away from my home. The waitress is very warm-heart. I will come again.
author: Lei W.

description: Another spicy place! I like the Green onion pancake, water boil fish, and sichuan chicken.  Had to try more dishes to say more.  But this place is packed, good business. I will update next time with more dishes.
author: Jasmin Y.

description: Did not like this place at all.  Customer service was OK, but they messed up our order because they do not speak English, yet we had to pay for the extra dish.  We ordered three dishes and all three of the dishes were tasteless!  If you just want spicy /hot food  lacking in flavor, then this is the place for you.  Or you can simply use  a handful of Szechuan Peppers in your dish at home.   Will not go back.
author: G J.

description: The place is so good i had to write my first review. Everything tastes so light and fresh and not msg packed / grease ridden like a lot of other chinese restaurants. I got the Spicy Fish Soup and it practically tasted like back at home!
author: Jimmy W.

description:
This place has authentic Sichuan spicy food. I'm judging it as a Sichuan native.  

Service at this restaurant is exceptional good, considering most Chinese restaurants do not have good customer service. The owner and serving staff are warm and sweet. They're all proud of the tasty food served at their restaurant.  We got free Sichuan style pickles as appetizer. In addition to that, they served free desert -Chinese sweet rice donut after the meal. 

Good value for your money!
author: Sheila S.

description: I eat out a lot and I have to say this place may have had a bad day when I was there or else used a lot of salt/MSG for our dishes.  Went for lunch and had dumplings, noodles and another signature dish.  None were memorable.  Maybe I have to try again later.
author: Amorette K.

description: Better than Chili House. Too bad they don't accept online orders through seamless or grubhub.
author: Robert S.

description: The only REAL SPICY Sichuan food place I found in the United States.
author: Shirley W.

description:
Best spicy water boil fish I've ever had (although I am Chinese, I will admit I've only had this fish dish at maybe 5 restaurants b/c I'm Canto). Get the one for $25, it comes as a hot pot with its own gas burner. (There is a picture of it posted by ChenTao X. at http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/9MIVq95YYLQyGODDsdAbOA?select=WschM5D_LanLxSjFlYMSzA) The fish is delicate, plentiful, and the dish has plenty of yummies in it, like  glass noodles, black fungus, soy bean sprouts. I am a lover of spice, I've never had anything too spicy, and even I think they can totally turn up the heat.

Soup-filled dumplings are good.

The spicy lamb dish is so-so. 

Do not get the spicy wontons or the smoked duck appetizer. The wontons are not good at all - I have no idea why there are positive reviews of it; my table of three did not enjoy. The wontons are thick, very little meat, and the hot oil is nothing special. I can make better wontons at home. I prefer my wontons to be delicate shells with generous amounts of meat. Maybe this is a north vs. south issue? The smoked duck is freakin' salty.

The spicy chicken that has bone-in (sorry, I forget the name here, it's a very standard Szechuan dish) is good: crispy, nicely flavored with spice and salt.

Dan-dan noodles are nothing special. 

They do a number of cold dishes well, like the couple's delight.

Place is small, and can get a bit full, though I think a lot of people don't know about it yet. Fish here is superior to the fish at Z&Y, although the chicken at Z&Y is better. Metered parking, though you can find free street parking in the neighborhood if you search. Bathroom situation not so great b/c you have to go into the kitchen to get to it.

Service is reasonable, and if you speak Mandarin, you will get great service and perhaps a free item (sadly, I do not speak Mandarin). Run here if you want good Szechuan food.
author: B B.

description: Really good Szechuan flavors. My spicy soup noodles looked like an unappetizing big bowl of chili oil but it was so flavorful. The glass noodles just had the perfect texture. Level of spicy was just right. The house special fried rice was surprising good also. Had large slices of chicken & good sized shrimps in it. Best of all, it wasn't greasy or darkened with alot of soy sauce. Want to go back & try more
author: Jenny W.

description: underwhelmed. the owner kept asking us "isn't this best sichuan you have ever had?" eh no, it was kind of bland actually. just make it spicy hot, how hard can it be?
author: YM L.

description: Love this place.  Everything we've ordered here has been fabulous.  The Chef's special vegetarian dish is so delicious, we get it each time to compliment the other spivey dishes.  Fish stew is awesome, fish hot pot is awesome, stir fried chicken is awesome!!!  Our favorite Chinese place.
author: Daisy W.

description: Six of us ordered different entries each, and the quality is FAR from consistent. I had the schezuan-style spicy chicken, and it was the worst food I've had in the city. One entree a friend ordered was recommended by the server and was quite good, but the rest was junk. My food was salty to the point of becoming inedible, I couldn't finish a quarter of the chicken before completely giving up. Would NOT recommend unless you go with someone who knows their menu well enough to know what to avoid.
author: Matt F.

description: We had a very nice dinner here.  The waitresses all seemed very nice and maintained composure in spite of the Saturday night crush.  The special fish stew was good, and slightly different than versions of the same dish found at other szechuan places.  By comparison, the dry fried oyster dish was not something to ordered again (oysters felt a bit overcooked and the flavors weren't so thrilling).  Of course, I would rather not navigate my way through the kitchen to get to the bathroom, but nevertheless we will return and explore the menu more.
author: Richard P.

description: 4.5  good place for a new style sichuan.  try the Chef's Special Vegetable Combo to findout.  perfectly crunchy and tasty.  the chef's special fish stew is not the classic water boiled fish with sichuan peppercorns, but is still a large portion of more firm fish with milder fragrant spice.  avoid the deep fried chongqing chicken without bone.  fresh watermelon juice
author: Rob C.

description: love that they offer complimentary seaweed and spicy kimchi-ish cabbage.  most dishes were solid with the exception of xiao long baos(skippable)  green onion pancake had just the right amount of crisp with the inside still flaky.  fish stew had a good kick, not to mention the dish itself was gigantic!  there were leftovers at the end that i gladly volunteered to take home.  my fave was definitely definitely the taro stir fry.  julienned taro and chives make the perfect combination.  just a warning that they do NOT appreciate lingering and they made it known by prematurely clearing our table, even when some of us were STILL EATING!  i mean i understand that the place is small and we're taking up one of the few big tables and there's people waiting and we might not have ordered the most expensive dishes on the menu, but golly we were only there for an hour.  give us some time to digest a bit before shooing us out!
author: Melissa Y.

description:
i am always on the mission of finding authentic chinese food in the city, and this place is one of my fav so far.

the place is very small, and not fancy, fyi. but the service is pretty good, and the owner lady is very nice.

price is very fair, good amount of food for sure, much cheaper than chinatown.

things we've tried:

spicy chicken, so good.

bean paste noodles, not as good as they are in china, but pretty ok compared to other restaurants in the city.

spicy fish, lots of fish in there, very flavorful. very tasty.

pan fried pork bun, not bad but not the best.

chef special stir fry, has lots of taro in it. so good.

twice cooked pork, very good too.

xiaolongbao, decent.
author: Danielle A.

description: this place is why the Richmond has the best Asian food in the city. places like this. unassuming and normal looking little spot with all kinds of tasty goodness. good variety, lots of secret chefs specials, no folded napkins or fortune cookies. Fish soup, dumplings noodles all perfection and all kinds of fire for the mouth here..  friendly service, free tea, and reasonable prices.
author: J o.

description:
For a Sichuan restaurant, they were very accommodating with requests to tone things down.    Just because I can't handle spice doesn't mean I don't like the other flavors and styles of Sichuan food. 
The house veggie platter was bizarre and great.  Crispy taro strips, strips of lotus root, green chives and some pine nuts.  Great textures... mild unique flavor.   Can't eat it too fast, as the crispy taro could poke your mouth if you're not careful.  
Got Cumin lamb and asked for it to be made mildly.  Pretty great. I could have done with even more cumin flavor, but it wasn't overly oily, and no peppers at all.  
Nutritional Mutton soup was also a big hit.  I am a big fan of Chinese medicinal soups.  They are pretty hard to find in SF.   Big chunks of lamb/mutton (some more chewy than others), but I was really in it for the broth anyway.
Complimentary seaweed and cabbage was good too, and until the bottom where the chili oil pooled, it wasn't too hot. 
I've noticed other reviews mention taming down some of their dishes so it looks like this is a good compromise for those of us who like everything about Sichuan food but the overly spiciness.
author: howard t.

description: Came here with my girlfriend since she loves spicy food. I figured I would check to see if they had any current deals and found a nice discount after searching for "Sichuan home voucher" on google. Turns out it is a small restaruant and nothing fancy... but the food was surprisingly good and wonderfully presented. The girlfriend thought the chefs special fish was very tasty, and if she loved it, that's good enough for me.
author: karry m.

description: Oh my what a delightful find. I was not very hungry so I ordered a noodle soup with pork. Fantastic! I am going back for lunch tomorrow. Sparkling Clean Dining area and Kitchen. I need to sample an entre before I say more about the food, but based on the soup I had I anticipate a great dining experience.
author: Mac M.

description: Food is pretty good but prices are high here. Got several dishes here. Couple's Delight is one of my favorite Sichuan dishes. Its very good here. But when I tried take out, they gave me a smaller portion than I was expecting at pretty much $9 for that dish, I sort of felt a bit ripped off. Anyway, the fish in spicy soup had lots of fish in it, another expensive dish, but it really didn't taste all that good in terms of seasoning, just hot. Its marked as a special but to me I didn't care for it very much. They also had some taro and vegetable sliver dish, it was crunchy and pretty good. I'd come back but not very often as this place is expensive. Also its very hard to find parking around this area. I also don't like plastic chopsticks as its hard to hold food with them.
author: Dijon Y.

description: Pretty good szechuan food but REALLY spicy! Beware of that if you're a mild spicy person like me. I know if I had the tolerance and tastebuds to handle it, I would love it. But I was dying of the spices! Need water! Lots of it!
author: Jeanne C.

description: We ate here for the first time last night. Wow! this place serves delicious food. Everything ordered was so good.The service is friendly. Nothing fancy inside the restaurant, but it's clean. We will be coming back here.
author: Joe M.

description: Have been back to Sichuan Home maybe 7-8 times since last year's review and the food has stayed consistently good- it's my new favorite Chinese restaurant in SF, elevating it above Mission Chinese and R&G Lounge! We've tried so many new things and on occasion the chef's sent us out an extra dish just for good measure when we bring a large group- super nice. The variety of great spicy and non-spicy dishes makes it easy to please so many of our friends' palates. staff is great and you're never gonna leave hungry or broke when you eat here. They just celebrated their 1-year anniversary, congrats!
author: Aileen T.

description: Excellent food served family style on the larger 6 top tables.  Came with a group and got to try several dishes.  My personal favorites were the chef special fish (be prepared for hot, but tasty), red oil wantons, and the fried pumpkin.  I am just not Chinese enough to enjoy the bone in items - smoked duck, prawns, chicken in pot.  I know this is traditional Chinese style.  I just have a hard time separating the bones in my mouth
author: Wade T.

description: This restaurant is a gem. Great for folks looking for fresh and authentic food. The staff are so helpful and I have tried many new dishes, all delicious. Very reasonable prices too. There are so many mediocre Chinese restaurants in the Richmond district. We are pleased to now have Sichuan Home in the neighborhood. You won't be disappointed.
author: Beth C.

description: this place was fantastic, loved the kung pao chicken, loved the spiciness level of all the dishes, which for a lot of folks is probably too spicy.
author: Jonathan J.

description: I was so surprised by the poor quality of the food I had to come home and write a review immediately.  I was looking forward to taking my sister who was coming in from Miami there since she cannot get great Asian food where she lives.  After reading other reviews I picked her up from the airport and went to Sichuan Home for lunch. The plate I was given to use had dried food on it-they apologized and did give me a clean one but it was not a great start.  I ordered Szechuan beef-the meat was  tough and dry. I could not eat it without risking the possibility of choking when I swallowed.  The steamed rice was limp and tasteless.  My sister ordered chicken with mixed vegetables and said that although it was not great, it was edible.  The wonton soup which we shared was watery and tasteless.  We did not bother to take home any of the left overs which I usually love for breakfast the next morning. So sorry I could not agree with previous reviews.
author: Rose G.

description: After seeing this place on Yelp, I got the chance to experience it a week ago.  It is a small place, but as they say, big things come in small packages.  The service is very friendly and prices reasonable.  They are very patient and answer any questions you have especially since it is an authentic menu with very little if not any Americanized dishes, but, not to worry, nothing out of the ordinary.  Not being in the mood, for spicy, we ordered everything a little spicy which to them met mild, but was still every bit as good, packing a little spice.  The pot stickers are crispy golden with a wonderful ground pork, cabbage, and ginger filling; perfect topped with a little soy sauce; the wrappers not too thin or thick.  The chef's special chicken is crispy and greasless with chili peppers and black pepper; a perfect amount of heat with dry fried goodness; I love the Chinese crackers accompanying it that have a very bready taste and remind me of Chitos as far as the shape and consistency.  The tan tan noodles, my favorite Szechuan dish are served in a chili broth with fresh peanuts, ground pork, and cabbage; not a chili sauce or peanut or peanut chili sauce like at other places; packed the right amount of spiciness.  I loved the green bean soup (not the green beans you would use in chili garlic sauce) for anyone discovering this dish; a lightly sweet soup of goodness.  So, for excellent Szechuan cuisine in a clean atmosphere with friendly service, Szechuan Home cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.
